revision.text:
[[File:Full portrait witzel 1920.jpg|thumb|Al St. John studio portrait, 1920]]
[[Al St. John]] (1893-1963) was an American comic actor who appeared some 350 or more films between 1913 and 1952. Starting at [[Mack Sennett]]'s Keystone Film Company, St. John rose through the ranks to become one of the major comedy stars of the 1920s, though less than half of his starring roles still survive today. With the advent of sound drastically changing and curtailing the two-reel comedy format, St. John diversified, creating a second career for himself as a comic sidekick in Western films and ultimately developing the character of "Fuzzy Q. Jones," for which he is best known in posterity.
==Starring Al St. John==
St. John's first starring roles were made at Keystone, but most of these were made at the very end of the history of the company, just as Mack Sennett was abandoning the "Keystone" moniker in order to extricate himself from the [[Triangle Film Corporation]] partnership. St. John got a second chance at solo stardom starting in 1919 with [[Paramount Pictures]] and the early [[Warner Bros.]] studio, and this led to extended series of 2-reel comedies for [[Fox Film Corporation]] and [[Educational Pictures]]. Al St. John starred in more than 70 2-reel comedies through 1932. This is the most important part of his personal legacy, but it remains the least accessible part of his activity. Changes to this list are inevitable, and are welcomed.

==Fuzzy Q. Jones Roles==
"Fuzzy Q. Jones" was developed when Al St. John filled in for actor Fuzzy Knight on a film Knight was unable to make. St. John made more than 80 western films in this character, which proved indispensable to the PRC studio and so popular that "Fuzzy Settles Down" (1944) remains the only American B-Western that is titled after the sidekick. In post-war Germany, where Fuzzy was especially popular, he was always billed in the title of his pictures, despite the presence of the hero. It was as Fuzzy—whom Al came to regard as a separate person, apart from himself—that St. John finished out his long film career. These films had, in many cases, multiple theatrical distributors, and most of the PRCs were re-released in the 1950s by Madison Pictures, though in some instances in cut down versions. In cases where a television vendor is the more likely medium through which one may see a given title, the vendor is listed in the distribution field is given rather than the original theatrical distributor. A listing for a home video does not automatically mean that the title is still available for viewing. All of these films were made in sound, and are extant.

==With Roscoe Arbuckle and/or Buster Keaton==
Al St. John's association with his uncle, Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle, was central to his film career. Arbuckle first brought St. John to the Keystone set in 1913; over the years to follow, Arbuckle routinely employed St. John in playing rubes, rivals and other parts in support of his popular "Fatty" character. When Arbuckle left Keystone in early 1917 to form the Comique Comedy unit at Paramount, he and St. John were joined by stage comedian Buster Keaton, and the three created a singular cycle of silent comedies that exploited their matched acrobatic abilities and hard-driving capabilities in slapstick. This section represents onscreen appearances in films by St. John with either Arbuckle, Keaton or both, and it remains the most accessible area of Al St. John's silent comedy work. Arbuckle-directed comedies starring Al St. John are listed in the "Starring Al St. John" section above.<ref>Although previously listed here, Al St. John does not appear in the following Keystone, according to Brent Walker in ''Mack Sennett's Fun Factory'' (McFarland, Jefferson NC 2013): [[The Gangsters]].</ref>

==Supporting Roles: Shorts==
Upon his arrival at Keystone, Al St. John was swiftly absorbed into the Keystone repertory company; he appeared in more 1914 films than Charlie Chaplin did. After Keystone, St. John appeared in support of other comics in 2-reelers up to the end of the silent era. Appearances in films with Roscoe Arbuckle are included in the list above. This list may be incomplete, as the full extent of St. John's appearances of this kind is not known, owing to so many lost films that may serve as possible candidates. For Keystones, the principal actor is included, though in many cases it is unclear who within the film that may be. Owing to the ensemble nature of many early Keystones, there are films which essentially do not have a central comedian as the fixture, and outside of Charlie Chaplin, survival rates on Keystones are less than what would be ideal. Unconfirmed appearances are not included in this list.<ref>Although previously listed here, Al St. John does not appear in the following Keystones, according to Brent Walker in ''Mack Sennett's Fun Factory'' (McFarland, Jefferson NC 2013): Soldiers of Misfortune (1914), He Loved the Ladies (1914).</ref>

==Supporting Roles: Features==
With the dawn of sound around 1930, Al St. John went from appearing almost exclusively in two-reel shorts to appearing almost exclusively in features. While his Fuzzy Q. Jones roles dominate St. John's feature output, he did appear in a number of features in other parts, mostly in Westerns. Some of these, particularly his serio-comic turn as "Uncle Billy" in The Outcasts of Poker Flat (1937), demonstrate a greater range of acting ability than the average Fuzzy Q. Jones role might suggest. Several parts listed here, however, are the tiniest of tiny bit roles.

{{Infobox person |name = Alfred Ritter von Kropatschek |image = File:Alfred von Kropatschek 1901 Huber.jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_name = Alfred Kropatschek |birth_date = {{Birth date|1838|01|30}} |birth_place = [[Bielsko]], [[Austrian Empire]] (present day [[Poland]]) |death_date = {{Death date and age|1911|05|02|1838|01|30}} |death_place =[[Lovran]], [[Austria-Hungary]] (present day [[Croatia]]) |employer = |occupation = Inventor, General |spouse= |children = }} '''Alfred Ritter von Kropatschek''' ([[Bielitz]], January 30, 1838 – [[Lovran]], May 2, 1911)[http://www.biographien.ac.at/oebl/oebl_K/Kropatschek_Alfred_1838_1911.xml Biography in the ''Österreichisches Biographisches Lexikon 1815 – 1950'']. was a [[general]] in the [[Austrian Army]] and a weapons designer of the late 19th century, who was responsible for several rifle and revolver designs in affiliation with the [[Steyr Mannlicher]]; these weapons were used by the armed forces of the [[Austrian Empire]] and several other nations. His rifles feature a tubular magazine under the barrel similar to a [[Winchester rifle]]; the [[cartridge lifter]] was the key to the Kropatschek design. One of his designs was sold to the [[French Navy]], and was later adapted by the [[French Army]] in the development of the prolific [[Lebel rifle]], which served as [[France]]'s front-line rifle from 1886 through the [[World War I|First World War]]. According to historian Roger A Pauly, some people joked that more bullets from Kropatschek-designed rifles were fired at the Austrians, than by them.{{cite book|title=Firearms: The Life Story of a Technology |author= Roger A. Pauly|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=0-313-32796-3|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=izGOfMdSm2IC&pg=PA111 | page=111}} Kropatschek's tubular magazine design was also adapted to the German [[Mauser Model 1871]] rifle, resulting in the Model 71/84. Kropatschek was a contemporary of [[Ferdinand Mannlicher]] in their affiliations with the Steyr munitions company, but they had competing designs. The Steyr Kropatschek rifles featured the tubular magazine and the Steyr Mannlicher rifles featured a box magazine. The limiting factors of the tubular magazines were: a risk of pointed tip bullets firing the primer of the next cartridge in the tube, and the lack of magazine capacity for short weapons such as carbines (shorter tubes). An advantage of the box magazine is quick reloading by inserting a full clip or by a [[stripper-clip]]. ==Rifle and revolver designs== ===Austria-Hungary=== Model 1881 Gendarmarie [[Carbine]] (also known as "M1874/81")
1881 Type Trials [[Rifle]]s ===France=== Model 1878 Navy rifle (''Fusil de Marine Mle 1878''),
Model 1884 Infantry Rifle (''Fusil d'Infanterie Mle 1884''),
Model 1885 Infantry Rifle (''Fusil d'Infanterie Mle 1885''). ===Portugal=== Model 1886 8 mm Infantry Rifle (''Espingarda de Infantaria 8 mm m/1886''),
Model 1886/89 8 mm Infantry Rifle with heat protecting handguard for colonial use (''Espingarda de Infantaria 8 mm m/1886/89''),
Model 1886 8 mm Light Infantry Carbine (''Carabina de Caçadores 8 mm m/1886'')
Model 1886 8 mm Cavalry Carbine (''Carabina de Cavalaria 8 mm m/1886''). ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kropatschek, Alfred Ritter von}} [[Category:1838 births]] [[Category:1911 deaths]] [[Category:Firearm designers]] [[Category:Austrian knights]] [[Category:Austrian generals]]

revision.text:
[[File:Athalya Brenner.jpeg|thumb|180px|Athalya Brenner]] '''Athalya Brenner-Idan''' (born 17 July 1943 in [[Haifa]], [[Israel]]<ref name=TAU>{{cite web|title=Prof. ATHALYA BRENNER|url=http://humanities.tau.ac.il/segel/abrenner/|publisher=[[Tel Aviv University]]|accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref>) is a Dutch-Israeli biblical scholar. She is currently Professor Emerita of Hebrew Bible/Old Testament at the [[University of Amsterdam]] and Professor in Biblical Studies at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Athalya Brenner |url=http://store.fortresspress.com/store/contributor/4653/Athalya+Brenner |publisher=[[Fortress Press]] |accessdate=27 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808215945/http://store.fortresspress.com/store/contributor/4653/Athalya%2BBrenner |archivedate=8 August 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Brenner studied at [[Haifa University]] and the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] before doing a PhD at the [[University of Manchester]] under the supervision of [[James Barr (biblical scholar)|James Barr]].<ref name=TAU /> She taught for a time at [[Oranim Academic College]].
Alice Ogden Bellis noted in 2007 that in recent years, more than any other woman, Brenner has been at the forefront of feminist biblical studies. Bellis goes on to suggest that in her book ''I Am: Biblical Women Tell Their Own Stories'', Brenner is "erudite, witty, clever, feisty, and not at all religious."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bellis|first=Alice Ogden|title=Review of ''I Am: Biblical Women Tell Their Own Stories''|journal=Journal of Religious Thought|year=2007|volume=60|page=195}}</ref>
She is currently president of the [[Society of Biblical Literature]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Officers of the Society|url=https://www.sbl-site.org/SBLcommittees_Council.aspx|publisher=[[Society of Biblical Literature]]|accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref>

{{Infobox tribe |name= Awamir |local name= العوامر |type= Arab tribe |image= |image_size= |caption= |ethnicity= [[Arabs|Arab]] |location= [[United Arab Emirates]]
[[Oman]] |descended= |population= 10,000 |branches= Afar |language= [[Arabic]] |religion= [[Islam]] |surnames= }} The '''Awamir''' ({{lang-ar|العوامر}}) (singular Al Amiri {{lang-ar|العامري}}) is a [[Bedouin]] Arab tribe in the [[United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates (UAE)]] and [[Oman]].{{Cite book|title=Gazetteer of the Persian Gulf Vol II|last=Lorimer|first=John|publisher=British Government, Bombay|year=1915|isbn=|location=|pages=186}} Warlike, fiercely independent and frequently murderous, they were camel breeders, raiders and occasionally date farmers before settling in the 1960s. == History == The Awamir roamed across the whole Oman peninsula, from [[Muscat]] and [[Nizwa]] to [[Abu Dhabi]] and [[Liwa Oasis|Liwa]]. The Awamir in the area of Abu Dhabi were considered affiliated to the [[Bani Yas]] and frequently supported them in conflicts.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=39|oclc=64689681}} A large tribe, the Awamir originated in the steppes to the north of the [[Hadhramaut|Hadhramut]], settling in the north in a process of migration which took place over 500 years.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=430|oclc=64689681}} A subsection of the tribe, 'Afar, was linked to Dhafrah. Some 4,000 Awamir settled outside of Oman proper at the turn of the 20th century and of the whole tribe, numbered at the time as 10,000 strong, some 3,500 were nomadic [[Bedouin]].{{Cite book|title=Gazetteer of the Persian Gulf Vol II|last=Lorimer|first=John|publisher=British Government, Bombay|year=1915|isbn=|location=|pages=187}} [[John Gordon Lorimer (civil servant)|J. G. Lorimer]] characterised the Awamir as "Reputed brave and warlike but crafty, treacherous and predatory; they are said to plunder indiscriminately all whom they meet..." == Bani Yas affiliation == In 1848, [[Saeed bin Tahnun Al Nahyan|Sheikh Saeed bin Tahnun Al Nahyan]] was spurred into action against the [[Emirate of Nejd|Wahhabis]] encamped in [[Al Buraimi Governorate|Buraimi]], capturing his two forts back with the help of the Awamir. The Awamir formed part of the tribal confederacy force he then pulled together and used to clear the oasis and block a relieving army under Sa'ad bin Mutlaq. By 1850, Saeed's great tribal association had cleared Buraimi Oasis of Wahhabi forces. He subsequently accepted a stipend from the [[Said bin Sultan, Sultan of Muscat and Oman|Sultan of Muscat]] for the defence of Buraimi.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=50|oclc=64689681}} The Awamir supported Saeed's successor, [[Zayed bin Khalifa Al Nahyan|Sheikh Zayed bin Khalifa Al Nahyan]] in his extended war with [[Qatar]] in the 1880s, a series of conflicts that secured the western border of Abu Dhabi.Al-Hajji 2001, pp 171-4 By the 1920s, the Awamir were central to a number of conflicts between the tribes around Buraimi and Abu Dhabi town, fighting with the [[Manasir (tribe)|Manasir]], [[Duru (tribe)|Duru]] and [[Bani Qitab]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/945874284|title=The Origins of the United Arab Emirates : a Political and Social History of the Trucial States.|last=Said.|first=Zahlan, Rosemarie|date=2016|publisher=Taylor and Francis|year=|isbn=9781317244653|location=|pages=83|oclc=945874284}} == Raiding == By the 1930s, the decline of pearling on the [[Trucial States|Trucial Coast]] had led to a general recession and the Awamir's raiding activities grew as demand for their camels and services as drivers dropped. The raids on [[Dubai]] alone were part of the general unrest (in a time of depression and poverty) felt by the people against their Ruler, [[Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum|Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum Bin Hasher Al Maktoum]], leading to the Majlis movement.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/945874284|title=The Origins of the United Arab Emirates : a Political and Social History of the Trucial States.|last=Said.|first=Zahlan, Rosemarie|date=2016|publisher=Taylor and Francis|year=|isbn=9781317244653|location=|pages=54|oclc=945874284}} In 1931 alone several such incidents included raids on [[camel train]]s, on settlements and date groves and, in at least one case, sheer vandalism in retaliation against a ruler's punishment of them: they cut down 20 unripe date palms in [[Umm Al Quwain]] following an outbreak of looting.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=231|oclc=64689681}} This raiding led to open conflict between tribes and Abu Dhabi found itself called to account on behalf of its unruly subjects as raids led to open and bloody warfare between tribes. For the first time, the British were forced to intervene in matters of the interior and broker an agreement between Abu Dhabi and Dubai over their border and the terms of a peace between the tribes.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=302|oclc=64689681}} The Awamir had long been in conflict with the Duru and in the 1940s, the ongoing conflict led the headman of the Bedouin Awamir, Salim bin Hamad bin Rakkad, to lead his people to [[Al-Hasa|Al Hasa]] in 1943. They returned in 1948, but in subsequent years were constantly drawn back to Hasa.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=40|oclc=64689681}} The bulk of the tribe remained at Buraimi and petitioned the [[Al Nahyan family|Al Bu Falah]] for protection. One of [[Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan|Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan']]s first acts when he was appointed ''[[wali]]'' of Al Ain was to call for Salim bin Mussalam bin Hamm and appoint him as head of the Bedouin Awamir. The portion of the tribe which had moved south under Salim bin Hamad became [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] citizens and this schism within the Awamir was later to form part of the territorial arguments put forward in the [[Buraimi Dispute]]. == Settlement == By the 1950s, some 50 families of the Awamir had acquired date plantations in Buraimi but few settled in Liwa. Staunchly nomadic and focused on breeding and herding camels, the Awamir had no interests in the pearling beyond casual work on the boats{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64689681|title=From Trucial States to United Arab Emirates : a society in transition|last=1941-|first=Heard-Bey, Frauke,|date=2005|publisher=Motivate|year=|isbn=1860631673|location=London|pages=174|oclc=64689681}} and remained essentially nomadic. By 1968, some 1,721 members of the Awamir were identified in a census, many of whom had taken up employment with the oil companies. == References == {{Reflist}}{{Arab tribes in the United Arab Emirates}} [[Category:Tribes of the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:History of the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Emirati people]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2016}} [[File:Sikh Gurus with Bhai Bala and Bhai Mardana.jpg|250px|thumb|right|A rare [[Tanjore painting|Tanjore]] style painting from the late 19th century depicting the ten Sikh Gurus with Bhai Bala and [[Bhai Mardana]].]] '''Bhai Bala''' ({{lang-pa|ਭਾਈ ਬਾਲਾ}} 1466–1544), born in Talvandi Rai Bhoi (now called [[Nankana Sahib]] in [[Pakistan]]),Into [[Hindu]] [[Jat]] family,<ref name="McLeod, W.H. 1968">McLeod, W.H., Guru Nanak and the Sikh Religion. Oxford, 1968.</ref><ref>[http://allaboutsikhs.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17 A Gateway to Sikhism | Early Gursikhs: Bhai Bala Ji - A Gateway to Sikhism<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> was a supposed childhood friend and lifelong companion of [[Bhai Mardana]] and [[Guru Nanak]]. According to the Bhai Bala Janam Sakhi's, he travelled with Guru Nanak and [[Bhai Mardana]] on all of their great journeys around the world including [[China]], [[Mecca]], and around [[India]]. He supposedly died in Khadur Sahib, in his late 70s, in 1544. There is currently ongoing debate surrounding the existence of Bhai Bala.<ref name="McLeod, W.H. 1968"/><ref name="Macauliffe">Max Arthur Macauliffe, 1909</ref>
==Bhai Bala's Existence==
There has been considerable discussion as regards to Bhai Bala's existence, particularly within the Sikh academic field. The reasons for this are:
[[Bhai Gurdas]], who has listed all Guru Nanak's prominent disciples (in his 11th Var), does not mention the name of Bhai Bala (this may be an oversight, for he does not mention Rai Bular either). However [[Bhai Mani Singh]]'s Bhagat Ratanwali, which contains essentially the same list as that by Bhai Gurdas, but with more detail, also does not mention Bhai Bala. There are a number of other anomalies, which Dr. Kirpal Singh has explicated in his Punjabi work `Janamsakhi Tradition.'<ref name="Singh, Dr Kirpal 2004">Singh, Dr Kirpal, Janamsakhi Tradition (An Analytical Study). Singh Brothers, 2004.(page 10)</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://sikhnerd.com/downloads/sikh/janamsakhi_tradition_dr_kirpal_singh.pdf |title=Janamsakhi Tradition – An Analytical Study |author= Dr. Kirpal Singh |accessdate=8 September 2012}}</ref>
Professor Surjit Hans also notes that the only role of Bhai Bala was to denigrate the name of Nanak and that Guru Nanak prophesizes about a greater bhagat (Hundal) to come:
''The first clue to grasping the true character of the Bala Janamsakhi is the fact that the persons related most closely to Guru Nanak are presented in uncomplimentary light. His father, Kalu, for instance, is a cruel man; he is greedy and ill spoken; he blames Mardana for spoiling his son; and Guru Nanak is rather chary of meeting him. Guru Nanak’s wife regrets marrying him, she is hot-tempered and full of anger. His mother-in-law is quarrelsome and hardhearted. His father-in-law curses his fate to have a son-in-law like Guru Nanak. The Guru’s constant companion, Mardana, is pleased with counterfeit coins and cast off clothes; he is all the time hungry.''<ref name="Hans, Professor Surjit 1988">Hans, Professor Surjit, A Construction Of Sikh History From Sikh Literature. ABS Publications, 1988. (page 205)</ref>
Also in the Bhai Bala Janamsakhi are several language inconsistencies. For example, the Sikh salutation 'Waheguru Ji Ki Fateh' is used in the Bala Janamsakhi, however this term only gained currency during the reign of [[Guru Gobind Singh]].
==See also== *[[Guru Nanak]] *[[Bhai Mardana]] *[[Panja Sahib]] *[[Nankana Sahib]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *http://www.sikh-history.com/sikhhist/gurus/bhaibala.html *http://allaboutsikhs.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bala, Bhai}} [[Category:1466 births]] [[Category:1544 deaths]] [[Category:Indian Hindu religious leaders]] [[Category:Sikh saints]] [[Category:People whose existence is disputed]] [[Category:16th-century Hindu religious leaders]] [[Category:Guru Nanak Dev]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox criminal | name = Bob Dalton | image_name = DaltonBob.jpg | image_size = 220px | image_alt = | image_caption = | nationality = American | birth_name = Robert Rennick Dalton | birth_date = {{Birth date|1869|05|13}}<ref>http://www.robinsonlibrary.com/social/pathology/criminology/crimes/daltongang.htm</ref><!-- {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} (Dead) {{Birth date and age|yyyy|mm|dd|mf=yes}} (Known month and day) {{Birth year and age|yyyy|mm}} (known month) {{Birth year and age|yyyy}} (known year) --> | birth_place = [[Cass County, Missouri]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1892|10|05|1869|05|13}} | death_place = [[Coffeyville, Kansas]], United States | cause = Gunshot | alias = | allegiance = [[Dalton Gang]] | motive = | charge = [[Bank robbery]], [[train robbery]] | conviction = | conviction_penalty = | conviction_status = | occupation = | spouse = | partner = | parents = James Lewis Dalton; Adeline Lee Younger | children = }} '''Robert Rennick Dalton''' (May 13, 1869 – October 5, 1892), better known as '''Bob Dalton''', was an [[United States|American]] [[outlaw]] in the [[American Old West]]. He led the ill-fated [[Dalton Gang]] raid on two banks in [[Coffeyville, Kansas]]. Ambushed by town citizens, Bob, [[Bill Power (outlaw)|Bill Power]], [[Grat Dalton]] and Richard L. "Dick" Broadwell were all killed.
==Early life== The Dalton family came from [[Jackson County, Missouri]]. Dalton's father, Lewis Dalton, was a [[bar (establishment)|saloon]] keeper in [[Kansas City, Kansas]], when he married Adeline Younger, the aunt of [[Cole Younger|Cole]] and [[Jim Younger]]. By 1882, the family moved to northeast Oklahoma, then known as the [[Indian Territory]], and by 1886 they had moved to [[Coffeyville, Kansas|Coffeyville]] in southeast Kansas. Bob was one of 13 of the couple's 15 children who survived to maturity. His siblings included: [[Frank Dalton|Frank]], [[Gratton Dalton|Grat]], [[William M. Dalton|Bill]] and [[Emmett Dalton|Emmett]].
Bob acquired a reputation for being dangerous after he killed a man at age 19. A deputy at the time, he claimed the killing was in the line of duty. The victim, however, was suspected of flirting with a man that Bob liked.<ref name="nps"> {{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/99condon/99facts2.htm |title=Reading 2: The Dalton Gang |author= |date= |work= |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=9 March 2011}} </ref>
==Lawman career== Bob's older brother Frank was a U.S.A.U. (meaning?) Deputy Marshal and Bob served with him on several [[Posse comitatus (common law)|posses]]. Frank was killed by a gang of horse thieves, the [[Smith-Dixon Gang]], on November 27, 1887<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gunslinger.com/dalton.html |title=The Dalton Gang |author=gunslinger.com |date= |work= |publisher=gunslinger.com |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511223239/http://www.gunslinger.com/dalton.html# |archive-date=2011-05-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and Bob may have been part of that posse.<ref name="legends"> {{cite web |url=http://www.legendsofamerica.com/we-daltonbrothers2.html#Bob%20Dalton |title=The Dalton Brothers - Lawmen & Outlaws |author=LEGENDS OF AMERICA |date= |work= |publisher=LEGENDS OF AMERICA |accessdate=6 March 2011}} </ref> After that incident Bob wished to be commissioned as a Deputy Marshal in the Western District at [[Fort Smith, Arkansas]] and was assigned to work for the [[Wichita, Kansas]] Court. Additionally, Dalton also served as the [[Chief of police]] for the [[Osage Nation]] while he was with the Kansas court.<ref name="legends"/>
On August 26, 1889, Dalton was sent to Coffeyville, Kansas to arrest a man named Charley Montgomery, who was charged with illegally selling whiskey and [[Horse thief|stealing horses]] in Indian Territory. Montgomery resisted arrest and drew his guns forcing Dalton to kill him with his pistol. Since there was no [[Bounty (reward)|bounty]] on Montgomery Dalton did not receive any payment when he returned with Montgomery's corpse to Fort Smith. When no one claimed the outlaw's body, as was the custom of the time, Dalton was required to pay for the burial.<ref name="legends"/>
In April 1890, both Dalton and his brother Grat were sent to [[Claremore, Oklahoma|Claremore, Indian Territory]] to arrest Alex Cochran who had been accused of killing U.S. Deputy Marshal Cox. The Daltons followed a rider fitting the description of the fugitive but the rider attempted to distance himself from the two deputies. The man refused to stop so, from a distance of 300 yards, Bob shot both the rider and his horse. The dead man, unfortunately, was Cochran's son, not Alex himself.<ref name="legends"/>
While Dalton continued to work as Police chief for the Osage Nation rumors began that he and his youngest brother Emmett were illegally selling whiskey to the Indians and the brothers became involved in a noisy disturbance with them. U.S. Commissioner Fitzpatrick called Bob Dalton in from the field, when he heard of the news, to demand his badge and discharge him from his position. Angered, Dalton claimed that he resigned, rather than being dismissed, over being cheated him out of several expenses.<ref name="legends"/> Charged with selling liquor in Indian Territory he would pay his [[bail]] but not appear for his trial.<ref name="nps" />
==Early outlaw career== In July 1890, Bob, Grat, and Emmett were accused of stealing horses near Claremore to sell them in Kansas. With a posse close behind of them Bob and Emmett left the territories for California where brother Bill was residing. Grat was arrested for the crime but would gain his release because of a lack of evidence. He would join his brothers in California.<ref name="slinger">{{cite web |url=http://www.gunslinger.com/dalton.html |title=The Dalton Gang |author=gunslinger.com |date= |work= |publisher=gunslinger.com |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511223239/http://www.gunslinger.com/dalton.html# |archive-date=2011-05-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
On the night of February 6, 1891 the Daltons raided a train operated by the [[Southern Pacific Railroad]], near [[Alila, California|Alila]], stealing $60,000. The boys were accused of the crime causing Bob and Emmett to flee the state, with a posse after them, while Grat and Bill were arrested. Grat would be found guilty on July 3, 1891 after a jury trial.<ref name="slinger"/>
==Next 18 months== Bob and Emmett retreated to the Indian Territories, but the law was still after them, so they decided to hide themselves. When Emmett worked, previously, at the [[Bar X Bar Ranch]] he became friends with cowboys [[Bill Doolin]] and Bill Power. Acquaintances of Emmett from other ranches included [[Charlie Pierce]], [[George Newcomb]], [[Charlie Bryant]], and Richard Broadwell.<ref name="slinger"/> Bob, as gang leader, decided they needed reinforcements and the future gang recruits were tough men who would help the brothers rob banks and trains throughout the [[Oklahoma Territory]] over the following 18 months.<ref name="legends"/>
The Dalton boys, at first, connected with Bryant and Newcomb in [[Wharton, Oklahoma Territory]] to rob a train in May 1891 earning $1745. Shortly after the robbery, Bryant fell ill and was taken to [[Hennessey, Oklahoma|Hennessey]] to see a doctor. After being spotted and arrested by Deputy Marshal Ed Short they killed each other during an escape attempt.<ref name="slinger"/>
On the night of September 15, 1891 they robbed the [[Missouri–Kansas–Texas Railroad|KATY train]] at [[Leliaetta, Oklahoma|Leliaetta]], near [[Wagoner, Oklahoma|Wagoner, Indian Territory]]. Bob and Emmett Dalton led Newcomb, Powers, Broadwell, Pierce and Doolin on the raid. The gang stopped and boarded the train and then stole $2500 from the express car.<ref name="slinger"/>
Grat escaped from jail on Sept. 18 while awaiting sentence in California and promptly returned to Oklahoma to rejoin his brothers. At the end of May 1892 the three Dalton brothers led Pierce, Newcomb, Powers, Broadwell, and Doolin on another train robbery. At the Red Rock train station, June 1, 1892, the gang positioned themselves to await an approaching train. A train entered the station with its coaches dark, which alerted the gang to a problem, so they allowed it to continue. A second train suddenly arrived which the gang boarded as it stopped at the station. They gang boarded it and robbed it but only collected $50. The gang later ed that the first train carried armed guards protecting $70,000 of the [[Sac and Fox Nation]] annuity.<ref name="slinger"/>
The gang made its last train robbery at [[Adair County, Oklahoma|Adair, Indian Territory]] on July 14, 1892. The train was again loaded with deputies, but the gang was quick and quiet enough not to disturb the marshals until the job was nearly completed. Exiting from the train the marshals engaged the gang in a violent but short gun battle. The battle claimed the life of an innocent bystander and wounded another. The Dalton Gang escaped without casualties and with the cash.<ref name="slinger"/>
==Coffeyville raid==
The gang split to pursue their own goals after the Adair raid. Bob and his brothers were deeply concerned with the pressure put upon them by the law. They decided to make one last robbery to earn enough money to leave the country. Their plan was to rob two banks in the same town at the same time to get the money and to also make history for accomplishing something that no other outlaw gang had even attempted. Their target was their old hometown of Coffeyville, Kansas.<ref name="slinger" />
Early on Oct. 5 1892, Bob, Grat, Emmett, Powers and Broadwell entered Coffeyville. Tying up their horses in the alley across from the banks, they walked across the street dividing into two groups before entering the Condon National Bank and First National Bank. Well known by the townspeople they were recognized and an alarm was given. Townsmen quickly armed themselves with guns from the local hardware stores and took positions to defend their town. As the Dalton Gang began their escape a gun battle erupted that killed gang members and four town citizens.<ref name="slinger" /> The lone survivor among the gang, Emmett, was seriously wounded receiving 23 gunshot wounds<ref name="legends"/> and he stood trial for the bank robberies after recovering. Sentenced to life in prison, he was granted a pardon by the governor after 14 years.<ref name="slinger" />
Deputy Marshal [[Heck Thomas]] remembered Bob Dalton as the most accurate shot he had ever seen. Dalton is buried at the Coffeyville, Kansas Cemetery under a group marker for himself, his brother Grat, and Bill Power.<ref name="legends"/>
The [[actor]] [[Forrest Tucker]] played Bob Dalton in the 1963 episode "Three Minutes to Eternity" of the [[Television syndication|syndicated]] [[Western (genre)|western]] [[television series]] ''[[Death Valley Days]]'', a dramatization of the simultaneous bank robberies in Coffeyville. [[Tom Skerritt]] portrayed the surviving [[Emmett Dalton]]; [[Jim Davis (actor)|Jim Davis]] was cast as [[Grat Dalton]]. The episode was narrated by [[Stanley Andrews]], known as "The Old Ranger".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0556909/?ref_=tt_ep_nx|title=Three Minutes to Eternity on ''Death Valley Days''|publisher=[[Internet Movie Data Base]]|accessdate=August 5, 2015}}</ref>
In 1975 Bob Dalton was played by the actor [[Robert Conrad]] in the TV movie western ''The Last Day''.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dalton, Bob}} [[Category:American bank robbers]] [[Category:Outlaws of the American Old West]] [[Category:Dalton Gang]] [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1892 deaths]] [[Category:Gunslingers of the American Old West]] [[Category:People from Cass County, Missouri]] [[Category:People from Coffeyville, Kansas]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Kansas]]

page.title: Cadency labels of the British royal family

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {| class="infobox" style="width:18em; text-align:left;" |+ style="padding-top:0.9em; line-height:160%;"| | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|
{{pad|0em}}'''Label and charges'''

[[File:Lambel.svg|160px]]
[[File:Badge of the Rouge Croix Pursuivant.svg|48px]]{{pad|1em}}[[File:Imperial Crown Heraldry.svg|48px]]{{pad|1em}}[[File:Tudor Rose.svg|48px]]
{{pad|.1em}}[[File:Heart*.svg|48px]]{{pad|1em}}[[File:Anchor (blue).svg|48px]]{{pad|1em}}[[File:Scottish Thistle (Heraldry).svg|48px]]
{{pad|0em}}[[File:Fleur de lys (azure).svg|48px]]{{pad|1.2em}}[[File:Escallop (red).svg|45px]]{{pad|1.2em}}[[File:Shamrock of Ireland (Heraldry).svg|40px]] |} Heraldic '''[[Label (heraldry)|labels]]''' are used to [[cadency|differentiate]] the personal [[Coat of arms|coats of arms]] of members of the [[royal family of the United Kingdom]] from that of the monarch and from each other. In the Gallo-British heraldic tradition, cadency marks have been available to "difference" the arms of a son from those of his father, and the arms of brothers from each other, and traditionally this was often done when it was considered important for each man to have a distinctive individual coat of arms and/or to differentiate the arms of the head of a house from junior members of the family. This was especially important in the case of arms of sovereignty: to use the undifferenced arms of a kingdom is to assert a claim to the throne. Therefore, in the English royal family, cadency marks were used from the time of [[Henry III of England|Henry III]], typically a label or bordure alluding to the arms of the bearer's mother or wife. After about 1340, when [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] made a claim to the throne of France, a blue label did not contrast sufficiently with the blue field of the French quarter of the royal arms; accordingly most royal cadets used labels [[argent]]: that of the heir apparent was plain, and all others were charged.''A Complete Guide to Heraldry'' by Arthur Charles Fox-Davies (1909), p. 494. (Online texts at https://archive.org/details/completeguidetoh00foxduoft or http://www7b.biglobe.ne.jp/~bprince/hr/foxdavies/index.htm .) Bordures of various tinctures continued to be used into the 15th century. ==The label== {{Main|Label (heraldry)}} In the ordinary system of differences a label of three points (which has also been termed a label with three files) is the distinction of the eldest son during the lifetime of his father. In the oldest rolls of arms the labels are all of five points; but labels of three points were at an early period used interchangeably. Besides being used as mere temporary marks of cadency, labels are also employed as permanent distinctions, borne (like any other charge) by every member of some particular branches of certain families. Labels are the principal cadency marks used in certain royal families. In the British royal family, all labels are ''[[argent]]'' (white). The sons and daughters of the sovereign all bear labels of three points argent; that of the [[Coat of arms of the Prince of Wales|arms of the Prince of Wales]] is plain, but all others are charged. Further descendants of princes bear labels of five points charged. All such differences should be borne on the arms, crest, and supporters. ==Charges== {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[File:Badge of the Rouge Croix Pursuivant.svg|65px]]

Red Cross ! [[File:Tudor Rose.svg|65px]]

Rose ! [[File:Heart*.svg|60px]]

Heart ! [[File:Fleur de lys (azure).svg|60px]]
Fleur-de-lis
blue ! [[File:Anchor (blue).svg|55px]]

Anchor ! [[File:Scottish Thistle (Heraldry).svg|70px]]

Thistle ! [[File:Shamrock of Ireland (Heraldry).svg|55px]]

Trefoil ! [[File:Heraldique lion passant fin méd.svg|60px]]

Red Lion ! [[File:Fourrure héraldique Hermine.svg|25px]]

Ermine ! [[File:Imperial Crown Heraldry.svg|65px]]

Crown ! [[File:Escallop (red).svg|55px]]

Escalope ! [[File:Meuble héraldique Abeille 64.svg|55px]]

Bee ! [[File:Disc Plain red.svg|55px]]

Roundel |} The system of a special mark for difference for each member of the family goes back to the time of [[Henry III of England|Henry III]], whose successor, as a prince, placed such a mark on the shield of England. Since 1340 this label has almost always been white, and overlaid with small figures, or charges, such as red [[St George's cross|crosses of St George]].[[Ottfried Neubecker]] & [[John Brooke-Little]]: ''Heraldry: Sources, Symbols and Meaning'' (1997). {{ISBN|0-316-64141-3}}. "Signs of Differencing" (pp. 96–97). This red cross represents England and its [[patron saint]], and was first borne by Richard of Bordeaux (future king [[Richard II of England|Richard II]]) before the death of his father [[Edward, the Black Prince]] in 1376. Other charges used: * A '''blue anchor''', a symbol of hope, or of naval service, as borne by several Dukes of York. * The '''Crown''' of England (sometimes called the Imperial or [[St Edward's Crown]]) borne by the abdicated king the [[Duke of Windsor]], which is as unusual as the occurrence itself. * '''[[Rose (symbolism)|Roses]]''': the [[Tudor Rose]] (combined red and white) has been used as an English [[Royal Supporters of England|royal badge]] since 1485. * Red '''[[heart (symbol)|hearts]]''' may allude to the arms of [[Lüneburg]] (part of the Hanoverian arms) or – for the descendants of Edward VII and Alexandra of Denmark – to the [[coat of arms of Denmark]]. * The blue '''[[fleur-de-lis]]''' appears amongst the Royal Badges in England of the [[House of Stuart|Stuarts]]. * The '''[[thistle#Heraldry|thistle]]''' is an ancient badge of [[Scotland]]. * The '''escallop shell''' was traditionally a token of pilgrimage on the [[Way of St James]]. The shell in the labels of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|The Duke of Cambridge]] and [[Prince Harry]] alludes to their [[Diana, Princess of Wales|mother's Spencer]] arms. * The '''bee''' is a canting charge in the label of [[Princess Beatrice of York]]. * The '''[[trefoil]]''' is a badge of Ireland, associated with [[St Patrick]], who used it to illustrate the [[doctrine of the Trinity]]. ==Labels used since the Hanoverian succession== File:Arms of the United Kingdom.svg|UK Arms since accession of Victoria, 1837 File:Arms of Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.svg|Albert, Prince Consort File:Arms of Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.svg|Prince Alfred (as Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha) File:Arms of Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh.svg|Prince Alfred (as Duke of Edinburgh) File:Arms of Beatrice, Princess Henry of Battenberg.svg|Princess Beatrice File:Arms of Edward, Duke of Windsor.svg|The Duke of Windsor File:Arms of Mary, the Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood.svg|Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood File:Arms of Henry, Duke of Gloucester.svg|Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester File:Arms of George, Duke of Kent.svg|Prince George, Duke of Kent File:Arms of Margaret, Countess of Snowdon.svg|Princess Margaret File:Arms of Alexandra, The Honourable Lady Ogilvy.svg|Princess Alexandra File:Arms of Edward, Duke of Kent.svg|The Duke of Kent File:Arms of Michael of Kent.svg|Prince Michael of Kent File:Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg|The Prince of Wales File:Arms of Anne, the Princess Royal.svg|The Princess Royal File:Arms of Andrew, Duke of York.svg|The Duke of York File:Arms of Edward, Earl of Wessex.svg|The Earl of Wessex File:Arms of William of Wales.svg|The Duke of Cambridge File:Arms of Harry, Duke of Sussex.svg|The Duke of Sussex File:Arms of Beatrice of York.svg|Princess Beatrice of York File:Arms of Eugenie of York.svg|Princess Eugenie of York {| class="wikitable" |- | style="text-align:center; {{Infobox person |name = Charles August Selby |image = Charles August Selby.jpg |alt= |caption = Charles August Selby |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1755|10|24}} |birth_place = [[Biddlestone Hall]], [[Northumberland]], [[England]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1823|3|15|1755|10|24}} |death_place = [[Güldenstein]], [[Holsten]] |resting_place = |ethnicity = |spouse = |residence = |citizenship = |workplaces = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |notable_students = | nationality = British-Danish | known_for = | occupation = Merchant | awards = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Charles August Selby''' (24 October 1755 – 15 March 1823) was an [[English people|English]]-[[Danish people|Danish]] merchant and landowner. He built the [[Orupgaard]] [[manor house]] on [[Falster]] and [[Bækkeskov]] on [[Zealand]]. Salby also owned property in [[Copenhagen]], including [[Strandgade 24]] in [[Christianshavn]].
The [[Baron]]'s oldest son, the politician and landowner, Charles Borre Selby, inherited the estate.<ref name=OG>[http://www.orupgaard.dk/default.asp?menuid=298 "Orupgaards historie"], Orupgaard Gods. {{da icon}} Retrieved 22 November 2012.</ref><ref name=LFH>[http://www.lollands-herregaarde.dk/ "Orupgård"], Lolland-Falsters Herregårde. {{da icon}} Retrieved 22 November 2012.</ref>
==Biography== [[File:Øer 08 Ovrupgaard Ø 1867.jpg|thumbnail|left|Orupgaard was built by Selby.]] Educated by [[English Benedictine Congregation|English Benedictine]] monks in [[Douai]] in [[Flanders]], he then entered commerce. In 1773, he joined [[William Chippendale]]'s firm in Copenhagen which had interests in a sugar refinery. He was also associated with the Copenhagen<ref name="BruunHovgaard1893">{{cite book|last1=Bruun|first1=Carl|last2=Hovgaard|first2=Andreas Peter|last3=Rist|first3=Peter Frederik|title=Museum: Tidsskrift for Historie og Geografi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UwTAkFLINckC&pg=PA71|accessdate=1 December 2012|edition=Public domain|year=1893|publisher=Gyldendal|language=Danish|pages=71–}}</ref> firm of Handelshus Selby & Co., which later became Selby & Ter-Borch, and in 1795, the company was taken over by Selby's partner, the Austrian [[consul]] Thomas Ter-Borch.<ref name="Thalbitzer1906" /> Selby developed a profitable interest in West-Indian trade until 1795 when he bought [[Bækkeskov]] and the [[Bredeshave]] farm. There, he was successful in introducing English and Flemish methods of farming. He built a Neoclassical manor at Bækkeskov but surprisingly sold it again in 1805 for reasons unknown.<ref name=DBL>[http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Handel_og_industri/Grosserer/Charles_Selby "Charles Selby"], ''Dansk Biografisk Leksikon''. {{da icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2012.</ref> Selby was styled as [[Baron]] in 1796.<ref name="Thalbitzer1906">{{cite book|last=Thalbitzer|first=Sophie Dorothea Zinn|title="Grandmama" bekiendelser."|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RNMTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA110|accessdate=1 December 2012|edition=Public domain|year=1906|publisher=Gyldendalske boghandel, Nordisk forlag|language=Danish|pages=110–}}</ref>
After his first wife died in 1809, he bought [[Orupgård]] on the island of Falster, redesigning the manor and developing farming there. Through his second wife, he acquired [[Güldenstein]] in [[Holstein]] together with several farms in the vicinity where he applied model approaches to cattle farming and forestry for the remainder of his life. From his correspondence, it can be seen Selby was a well-educated, gentlemanly figure with an interest in art and aesthetics. He demonstrated strong affinities with Denmark, donating considerable sums for the reconstruction of its fleet.<ref name=DBL/>

[[File:Danny DeVito cropped and edited for brightness.jpg|thumb|220px|DeVito at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]] in July 2013]] The following is the filmography for American actor, producer, and director [[Danny DeVito]]. He has appeared in the films ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (film)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest]]'' (1975), ''[[Car Wash (film)|Car Wash]]'' (1976), ''[[Terms of Endearment]]'' (1983), ''[[Romancing the Stone]]'' (1984) and its sequel ''[[The Jewel of the Nile]]'' (1985), ''[[Ruthless People]]'' (1986), ''[[Throw Momma from the Train]]'' (1987), ''[[Twins (1988 film)|Twins]]'' (1988), ''[[The War of the Roses (film)|The War of the Roses]]'' (1989), ''[[Batman Returns]]'' (1992), ''[[Renaissance Man (film)|Renaissance Man]]'' (1994), ''[[Get Shorty (film)|Get Shorty]]'' (1995), ''[[Matilda (1996 film)|Matilda]]'' (1996), ''[[Man on the Moon (film)|Man on the Moon]]'' (1999), ''[[Drowning Mona]]'' (2000), ''[[Be Cool]]'' (2005), and added his voice to the 2012 film ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]''. He has been in the television series ''[[It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia]]'' as [[Frank Reynolds (It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia)|Frank Reynolds]] since 2006. He and wife [[Rhea Perlman]] founded the production company [[Jersey Films]] in 1992, which produced over a dozen films, including ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'' (1994), ''[[Erin Brockovich (film)|Erin Brockovich]]'' (2000), and ''[[Garden State (film)|Garden State]]'' (2004).{{cite web|last=Carlson|first=Erin|title=Danny DeVito 'Working On' Marriage to Rhea {{Infobox royalty | name = [[Maharajadhiraj]] [[Mirza]] [[Maharao]] [[Shri]]
Deshalji II | title = [[Sahib]] [[Baghatur|Bahadur]] | titletext = | more = | type = | image = Maharao Deshulji II.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | succession = [[Rao of Cutch|Maharaja of Kutch]] | moretext = | reign = 25 March 1819 − 26 July 1860 | reign-type = | coronation = | cor-type = | predecessor = [[Bharmalji II]] | pre-type = | successor = [[Pragmalji II]] | suc-type = | regent = | reg-type = | succession3 = | moretext3 = | reign3 = | reign-type3 = | coronation3 = | cor-type3 = | predecessor3 = | pre-type3 = | successor3 = | suc-type3 = | regent3 = | reg-type3 = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1814 | birth_place = | death_date = 1860 | death_place = | burial_date = | burial_place = | spouse = | spouse-type = Spouse | consort = | issue = [[Pragmalji II]] | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | issue-type = | full name = | era name = | era dates = | regnal name = | posthumous name = | temple name = | house = [[Jadeja]] | house-type = Dynasty | father = [[Bharmalji II]] | mother = | religion = | occupation = | signature_type = | signature = }} [[Maharajadhiraj]] [[Mirza]] [[Maharao]] [[Shri]] '''Deshalji II''' [[Sahib]] [[Baghatur|Bahadur]] (b 1814- d 1860) (reign: 1819-1860) was the [[Rao of Cutch]] belonging to [[Jadeja]] dynasty, who ascended the throne of [[Princely State of Cutch]] upon deposition of his father [[Bharmalji II]] by British.[http://www.royalark.net/India/cutch4.htm Cutch] He reigned during his minority, under a [[Council of Regency]], headed by Captain MacMurdo and composed of Jadeja chiefs.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=_YvOTYXzJdHirAen4vTCCg&ct=result&id=d16gAAAAMAAJ&dq=Deshalji+II+of+Kutch&q=Deshalji+II+#search_anchor] Bhuj:art, architecture, history.[http://uqconnect.net/~zzhsoszy/ips/misc/kutch_tree.html Jadeja Rulers of Kutch : Deshalji II (1814-1860)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613165408/http://uqconnect.net/~zzhsoszy/ips/misc/kutch_tree.html |date=June 13, 2011 }}[http://uqconnect.net/~zzhsoszy/ips/k/kutch.html Kutch State : Maharao DESALJI BHARMALJI II (Daishalji) 1819/1860] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605032616/http://uqconnect.net/~zzhsoszy/ips/k/kutch.html |date=June 5, 2011 }} ==Reign== During his reign Kutch suffered a [[1819 Rann of Kutch earthquake|severe earthquake in 1819]] followed by severe famine in 1823, 1825 & 1832. Further, Kutch was attacked by marauding band from [[Sindh]]. Rao Deshalji and his Dewan Devkaran with their mediocre power and the support of their brethren defeated Kesarkhan and Sher Bulandkhan the Muslim marauding band. Also they defeated the evil designs of Sindh’s Nagarparkar.[http://kutchguide.blogspot.com/2011/03/rulers-of-kutch.html RULERS OF KUTCH] Deshalji although 18 years of age took the management of law in his own hands. The trade with Africa especially Zanzibar improved significantly. Slowly and steadily the industrialization in Kutch got a setback which was started by Lakhpatji and Godji.[http://itihas.wordpress.com/][https://books.google.com/books?id=kVwhcDDhHQkC&pg=PA113&dq=Deshalji+II+of+Kutch&hl=en&ei=_YvOTYXzJdHirAen4vTCCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Deshalji%20II%20of%20Kutch&f=false The presence of a glass factory and good breed of horses led Maharao Deshalji II (1819-1960) to maritime long distance trade with Zanzibar and most of all with Sultan of Oman.] Makran, Oman, and Zanzibar: three-terminal cultural corridor in the western By Beatrice Nicolini, Penelope-Jane Watson. The maritime trade with [[Zanzibar]] and [[Oman]] grew. Also the glass factory started during reign of [[Lakhpatji]] by Ram Singh Malam at [[Madhapar]] helped industrialization. Further, breeding of good quality Kutchi horses was also encouraged by Deshaliji, which brought in fair amount of revenue. In the period of Deshalji II steps were taken to suppress infanticide, [[Sati (practice)|sati]] and the slave trade in the State. The educational system was also improved.[https://books.google.com/books?id=mjpXAAAAMAAJ&q=Deshalji+II+of+Kutch&dq=Deshalji+II+of+Kutch&hl=en&ei=_YvOTYXzJdHirAen4vTCCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAg] Cultural history of Gujarat:from early times to pre-British period.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=_YvOTYXzJdHirAen4vTCCg&ct=result&id=5J05AQAAIAAJ&dq=Deshalji+II+of+Kutch&q=Deshalji+#search_anchor] The Gujarat directory ==Family and Succession== He had eight wives and several sons of which [[Pragmalji II]] was declared [[Yuvraj]] by him, who ascended the throne after his death in 1860. One of his queens is responsible for erection of present-day temples at [[Narayan Sarovar]]. Rao Deshalji II came of age in 1834 and was invested with full ruling powers but in later life, due to ill health, he transferred his ruling power to his son & successor [[Pragmalji II]] in 1859 one year before his death.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=_YvOTYXzJdHirAen4vTCCg&ct=result&id=BNUgAAAAMAAJ&dq=Deshalji+II+of+Kutch&q=Deshalji+II+#search_anchor] The Hind Rajasthan, or, The annals of the native states of India, Volume 1, Part 1. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External Links== {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[Jadeja|Jadeja Dynasty]]||1814||1860}} {{s-reg|}} {{s-bef|before=[[Bharmalji II]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Cutch State|Maharaja of Kutch]]|years=1819-60}} {{s-aft|after=[[Pragmalji II]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deshalji 02}} [[Category:1814 births]] [[Category:1860 deaths]] [[Category:Maharajas of Kutch]] [[Category:Hindu monarchs]] [[Category:Gujarati people]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Eduard Mochalov | honorific_suffix = | native_name = Эдуард Валерьевич Мочалов
([[Chuvash language|Chuvash]] and [[Russian language|Russian]]) | native_name_lang = | image = Мочалов выступает на Акатуе.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Eduard Mochalov giving speech
at a national festival [[Sabantuy|Akatuy]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|08|22}} | birth_place = [[Ishterek]], [[Chuvash ASSR]] | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Eduard Mochalov''' is a former businessman from [[Russia]] who survived [[corporate raid]] on his business and took the path of a ″crusading journalist″,{{cite news|first=Max |last=Seddon |title=Russian farmer takes on corrupt officials |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/russian-farmer-takes-corrupt-officials |work=[[The Associated Press]] |date=2012-11-21 |accessdate=2012-11-21 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} bringing to light numerous facts of corruption among local officials. ==Biography== His [[Eccentricity (behavior)|eccentric behaviour]] and [[Performance art|performances]] brought him fame both on local and national level. Russian journalists often refer to him as ″[[Navalny]] of [[Chuvashia]]″.{{cite news|first=Anastasiya|last=Karimova|title=В Москву со своей "Взяткой"|url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/2021275|work=[[Kommersant]]|date=2012-09-24|accessdate=2012-10-23}} Mochalov is also a staunch supporter of his native [[Chuvash language]] which is listed in UNESCO [[Red Book of Endangered Languages]] as ″vulnerable″. His recent article in support of the language was qualified by the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] as an ″[[incitement to ethnic or racial hatred]] towards [[Russians]]″ despite [[lower court]] acquitting him. Mochalov himself denies presented charges and regards criminal proceedings against him as politically motivated.{{cite news|first=Zhanna|last=Ulyanova|title="Ни одна типография в Чувашии не соглашается печатать "Взятку""|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/social/2012/08/22/4733993.shtml|work=[[Gazeta.ru]]|date=2012-08-22|accessdate=2012-10-23}}{{cite news|title=Мочалов предложил поискать экстремизм в органах власти Чувашии|url=http://www.irekle.org/news/i165.html|work=Irĕklĕ Sămah|date=2012-09-14|accessdate=2012-10-23}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mochalov, Eduard}} [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian whistleblowers]] [[Category:Chuvash people]] [[Category:Russian dissidents]] {{russia-journalist-stub}}

{{Infobox military person |name=Frederick Schaefer |birth_date= |birth_place= [[Baden]] |death_date = 1862 |death_place= [[Murfreesboro, Tennessee]] |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= {{flagicon|USA|1861}} [[United States|United States of America]]
[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] |branch= {{army|USA}}
[[Union Army]] |serviceyears= 1861 – 1862 |rank= [[File:Union Army colonel rank insignia.png|35px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]], [[United States Volunteers|U.S.V.]] |commands={{flagicon|Missouri}} [[2nd Missouri Volunteer Infantry|2nd Missouri Infantry]] |unit= |battles=[[American Civil War]] *[[Battle of Pea Ridge]] *[[Siege of Corinth]] *[[Battle of Stones River]][[Killed in action|†]] |awards= |laterwork= }} '''Frederick Schaefer''' was a [[Germans|German]] revolutionary and [[Union Army]] [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] during the [[American Civil War]]. He was a brigade commander at the battles of [[Battle of Pea Ridge|Pea Ridge]] and [[Battle of Stones River|Stones River]] where he was killed in action. ==Biography== Schaefer was born in [[Baden]] and served in the armed forces there.[http://www.gutenberg.org/files/4362/4362-h/p2.htm Personal Memoirs of Philip H. Sheridan] He came to the United States as a result of his participation in the [[Revolutions of 1848]], and settled in [[Missouri]]. He was appointed colonel of the [[2nd Missouri Volunteer Infantry|2nd Missouri Infantry]] and assigned to the [[Army of the Southwest]]. His regiment was part of the understrength 2nd Division commanded by [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brig. Gen.]] [[Alexander Asboth]]. By seniority of his rank, Schaefer assumed command of the 1st Brigade.Shea p.332 During the battle of Pea Ridge, Asboth's division was primarily held in reserved. On the second day of the battle, Schaefer's brigade took part in [[Franz Sigel]]'s counterattack.Shea p.237 After the Union victory at Pea Ridge much of the Army of the Southwest was transferred to the Western Army Group commanded by [[Henry Halleck]]. Asboth's division was decreased to a brigade status in the [[Army of the Mississippi]]. Schaefer returned to regimental command during the [[siege of Corinth]]. During the [[Confederate Heartland Offensive|Kentucky Campaign]], Schaefer was on sick leave and his regiment was led by [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]] Bernard Laiboldt. When Schaefer returned to command he was once again the ranking officer in his brigade. He assumed command of the 2nd Brigade in [[Philip H. Sheridan]]'s 3rd Division of the [[XIV Corps (Union Army)|XIV Corps]]. During the battle of Stones River Schaefer's brigade was initially held in reserve of Sheridan's division. His men were soon on the front lines and eventually began to run low on ammunition. Not having an adequate supply on hand, Sheridan ordered his brigade commanders to fix bayonets and continue to resist the Confederate attacks. Sheridan's division was hard pressed throughout the first day of the battle and Schaefer became Sheridan's fourth brigade commander to fall in battle. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ===References=== * Shea, William & Earl Hess. ''Pea Ridge: Civil War Campaign in the West'' University of North Carolina Press, 1992. {{ISBN|0-8078-4669-4}}. {{DEFAULTSORT:Schaefer, Frederick}} [[Category:German revolutionaries]] [[Category:People of Missouri in the American Civil War]] [[Category:People of the Revolutions of 1848]] [[Category:German emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Union Army colonels]] [[Category:1862 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Hadley Castille | image = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=91vBzCaNTQ0 | alt = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Hadley J. Castille | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1933|03|03}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|10|25 |1933|03|03}} | origin = [[Leonville, Louisiana]] | instrument = [[Fiddle]] | genre = [[Cajun music|Cajun]] | occupation = Musician, [[fiddler]] | associated_acts = Hadley J. Castille and the Sharecroppers
Hadley Castille & The Louisiana Cajun Band | website ={{url|hadleyjcastille.com/}} }} '''Hadley J. Castille''' (March 3, 1933[[#Yule09|Yule 2009]], p. 49. – October 25, 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.kplctv.com/story/19917179/louisiana-fiddling-legend-hadley-castille-dies|title=Louisiana Fiddling Legend Hadley Castille Dies|first=Elona|last=Weston|accessdate=October 30, 2012|date=October 25, 2012}}) was a prominent [[Cajun]] [[fiddler]]. ==Early life== Castille was born to a [[Cajun French]] speaking family. His father was named François Castille. He learned to play the fiddle from his Uncle Cyprien Castille at around the age of 9.{{cite web|url=http://www.acadianmuseum.com/legends.php?viewID=56|title=Hadley J. Castille|accessdate=2010-06-08}} After moving around for a while, he ended up in [[Pecaniere]] – a small community near Leonville, LA. Here, he first heard "Jole Blon" by [[Harry Choates]] during a trip to the Silver Slipper, a grocery store and bar.[[#Brasseaux09|Brasseaux 2009]], p.157. The song inspired him to take up a new style of playing.[[#Yule09|Yule 2009]], p. 50. In the early 1950s, he started playing at Roy's Bar in [[Port Barre, LA]] and local house parties.[[#Yule09|Yule 2009]], p. 51. Also, they played on the KSLO "Amateur Hour" segments on Saturday mornings. After graduating, Castille moved to New Orleans to play in a country band. However, after four to five months he moved back to Leonville, and eventually enlisted in the [[US Army]]. The [[Korean War]] ended soon after arriving in [[Fort Hood, Texas]]. He spent his entire service in [[Killeen, Texas]], where he played in an on base band. After service, he backed off from music to focus on family and his plumbing business.[[#Yule09|Yule 2009]], p. 52. ==Festival du Voyageur== In the early 1980s, Castille was invited to perform at Le Festival du Voyageur, Western Canada's largest winter festival. This experience caused him to relearn old Cajun tunes and focus on sharpening his skills. He returned to the festival for the next 18 years. He started recording music and playing many festivals during this time. ==Later life== In his later life, Castille continued to perform with his sharecropper band, and also lead many workshops at festivals. ==Legacy== Castille's played Cajun music most his life. This earned Castille many awards over the years. He has been inducted into the Louisiana Hall of Fame. Also, he has received the Acadiana Folk Heritage Award from the Acadiana Arts Council. He has been inducted into the Northwestern University Hall of Master Folk Artists. His work with "200 Lines: I Must Not Speak French" has earned him a Cajun French Music Association Heritage Award.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hadley-J.-Castille/e/B000AQ2XW2/|title=Hadley J. Castille: Albums, Songs, Bios, Photos|accessdate=2010-06-08}} He received an honorable discharge from the United States Army having served during the Korean War. Also, his music has been heard in films, such as [[A Perfect World]] with [[Clint Eastwood]]. ==Discography== *200 Lines: I Must Not Speak French [[Swallow Records|Swallow]] 6088 (1991) *Cajun Swamp Fiddler [[Swallow Records|Swallow]] 6112 (1993) *Musique de Castille [[Swallow Records|Swallow]] 6123 (1995) *Along the Bayou Teche [[Swallow Records|Swallow]] 6078 (1997) *Cajun Christmas Delta Records (1997) *Quarante Acres et Deux Mulés (40 Acres and 2 Mules) [[MTE Records|MTE]] 5070-2 (2000){{cite web|url=http://web.lsue.edu/acadgate/music/castille2.htm|title=Hadley Castille|accessdate=2010-06-08}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Refrait [[Swallow Records|Swallow]] 6191 (2005) *Hadley's Dream (Le Reve' a Hadley) Acadiana Sounds ==References== {{reflist}} *{{Cite book|title=Louisiana Fiddlers|last=Yule|first=Ron|isbn=978-1-60473-295-5|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|date=October 5, 2009|ref=Yule09}} *{{Cite book|title=Cajun breakdown: the emergence of an American-made music|publisher=Oxford University Press|date=June 4, 2009|last=Brasseaux|first=Ryan|isbn=978-0-19-534306-9|ref=Brasseaux09}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Castille, Hadley}} [[Category:Cajun people]] [[Category:American fiddlers]] [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Cajun fiddlers]] [[Category:Cajun musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Louisiana]] [[Category:People from St. Landry Parish, Louisiana]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century violinists]] [[Category:20th-century American musicians]]

revision.comment: Updated the broken links for the books and editorials to reflect the update at the official website. www.thewordfoundation.org
revision.text:
{{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Harold W. Percival | image = Harold W. Percival.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = April 15, 1868 | birth_place = Bridgetown, Barbados, British West Indies | death_date = March 6, 1953 | death_place = New York City, US | resting_place = | occupation = Author | language = English | nationality = American | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''[[Thinking and Destiny]]'','' Man and Woman and Child'','' Masonry and Its Symbols'','' Democracy Is Self-Government'' | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Harold Waldwin Percival''' (15 April 1868 - 6 March 1953) was a philosopher and writer, best known for ''[[Thinking and Destiny]]'', in print since 1946. Between 1904 and 1917 he published ''The Word''. In 1950 he founded [[The Word Foundation]], Inc. to keep ''Thinking and Destiny'' and all of his other works in print.
==Biography== Harold Waldwin Percival was born in Bridgetown, Barbados, British West Indies in 1868 to parents of English descent. When his father died his mother moved to the United States, eventually settling in New York City.
Even as a young boy, Harold Percival was a seeker of truth. He was convinced that there were "wise ones" who could answer his many questions and impart knowledge. As a young man, one of his first experiences on his quest for knowledge came in 1892 when he joined the [[Theosophical Society]]. He would later help to organize the Theosophical Society Independent of New York and for many years serve as its president while also writing and lecturing.
In 1893, and twice during the next 14 years, Percival had the unique experience of being "conscious of Consciousness," a potent spiritual and noetic enlightenment.<ref>''Gale Encyclopedia of Occultism & Parapsychology'', Fifth Edition, Volume 2 Edited by J. Gordon Melton Page 1196 Gale Group 27500 Drake Rd. Farmington Hills, MI 48331 {{ISBN|0810394898}} (Volume 2)</ref> He stated that the value of that experience was that it enabled him to know about any subject by a process he called "real thinking." Because these experiences revealed to him more than was contained in Theosophy, he wanted to share this knowledge with humanity.
In 1902 Percival started to develop his own system. For over 30 years he worked on the manuscript that would lead to the writing of his magnum opus, ''[[Thinking and Destiny]]'', now more than 65 years in print. He subsequently published three books expanding upon topics in the light of his system: ''Man and Woman and Child'' (1951), ''Masonry and Its Symbols'' (1952 ) and ''Democracy Is Self-Government'' (1952).
Between 1904 and 1917 Mr. Percival published ''The Word'', a magazine with a worldwide circulation dedicated to the brotherhood of humanity. Percival's own articles earned him a place in Who's Who in America (1928–29).
In 1950, The Word Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization, was established for the purpose of making known to the people of the world the writings of Harold W. Percival.
==Influence== Percival’s works were noted as a major influence upon Richard Matheson, the famous science-fiction author. He said that his book ''The Path'' (1998) was based largely on ''[[Thinking and Destiny]]''.<ref>Matheson, Richard (1998). ''The Path: Metaphysics for the 90’s.'' [[The Word Foundation]], Inc. {{ISBN|091165013X}}</ref>
In the book, ''The [[Bhagavad Gita]]: The Song of the Exalted Self'', 1999, by Owen Slight, the author states that Harold W. Percival’s ''Thinking and Destiny'', like the [[Bhagavad Gita]], reveals relevant, instructive and long lasting lessons regarding the higher self and the human plight—long lost lessons of everlasting truth contained both in the Sanskrit ''Bhagavad Gita'' and ''Thinking and Destiny''. Both books contain complete systems of knowledge. The plight of [[Arjuna]] is shown by Percival to be our own.<ref>Slight, Owen, The Bhagavad Gita: The Song of the Exalted Self, Owen Slight Publisher, 1999 {{ISBN|064635602X}}, 9780646356020</ref>
==Works==
===Books=== *''Thinking and Destiny''[https://thewordfoundation.com/thinking-and-destiny/] *''Man and Woman and Child''[https://thewordfoundation.com/man-and-woman-and-child/] *''Democracy is Self-Government''[https://thewordfoundation.com/democracy-is-self-government/] *''Masonry and its Symbols''[https://thewordfoundation.com/masonry-and-its-symbols/]
===Editorials=== Percival wrote the following editorials for ''The Word'' between 1904 and 1917: {{div col|colwidth=18em}} *"Adepts, Masters and Mahatmas"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Adepts-Masters-and-Mahatmas-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Personality"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Personality-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Psychic Tendencies and Development"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Psychic-Tendencies-and-Development-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Sex"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Sex-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Shadows"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Shadows-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Sleep"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Sleep-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Soul"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Soul-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Substance"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Substance-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Thought"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Thought-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Veil of Isis, The"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/The-Veil-of-Isis-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Will"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Will-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Wishing"[https://thewordfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Wishing-by-Harold-W-Percival.pdf] *"Zodiac,
