{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] | name = The Lord Houghton | honorific-suffix = [[Royal Society|FRS]] | image = Milnes.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = Lord Houghton | birth_date = 19 June 1809 | birth_place = London, England | death_date = {{death-date and age|11 August 1885|19 June 1809}} | death_place = [[Vichy]], France | nationality = British | party = [[Tory (political faction)|Tory]]
[[Whig (British political faction)|Whig]] | alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] | spouse = Hon. Annabel Crewe (d. 1874) }} '''Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron Houghton''', [[Royal Society|FRS]] (19 June 1809 – 11 August 1885) was an English poet, patron of literature and politician. ==Background and education== Milnes was born in London, the son of [[Robert Pemberton Milnes]], of [[Fryston Hall]], Castleford, [[West Yorkshire]], and the Honourable Henrietta, daughter of [[Robert Monckton-Arundell, 4th Viscount Galway]]. He was educated privately, and entered [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], in 1827.{{acad|id=MLNS827RM|name=Milnes, Richard Monckton}} There he was drawn into a literary set, and became a member of the famous [[Apostles Club]], which then included [[Alfred Lord Tennyson]], [[Arthur Hallam]], [[Richard Chenevix Trench]], [[Joseph Williams Blakesley]], and others. After graduating with an M.A. in 1831, Milnes travelled abroad, spending some time at the [[University of Bonn]]. He went to Italy and [[Greece]], and published in 1834 a volume of ''Memorials of a Tour in some Parts of Greece'', describing his experiences.{{sfn|Saunders|1894}} ==Political career== Milnes returned to London in 1837, and was elected to Parliament as member for [[Pontefract (UK Parliament constituency)|Pontefract]] as a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]]. In parliament he interested himself particularly in the question of [[copyright]] and the conditions of reformatory schools. He left [[Prime Minister]] [[Sir Robert Peel, 2nd Baronet|Sir Robert Peel]]'s party over the [[Corn Law]] controversy, and was afterwards identified in politics with [[Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston|Lord Palmerston]]. His easy good nature had the effect that his political career was viewed with less seriousness by his contemporaries than it might otherwise have been. In 1848, he went to Paris to see something of the revolution, and to fraternise with both sides. On his return he wrote, as a ‘Letter to Lord Lansdowne,’ 1848.{{sfn|Saunders|1894}} During the [[Chartism|Chartist]] riots of 1848, [[Matthew Arnold]] wrote to his mother:
Tell [[Harriet Martineau|Miss Martineau]] it is said here that Monckton Milnes refused to be sworn in a [[Special Constabulary|special constable]], that he might be free to assume the post of President of the Republic at a moment's notice.[[George W. E. Russell]], Collections & Recollections (Revised edition, Smith Elder & Co, London, 1899), at page 53.
In 1863, Palmerston elevated Milnes to the peerage as '''Baron Houghton''', of Great Houghton in the West Riding of the County of York.{{London Gazette |issue=22760 |date=7 August 1863 |page=3945 }} [[George W. E. Russell]] said of him: "As years advanced he became not (as the manner of most men is) less Liberal, but more so; keener in sympathy with all popular causes; livelier in his indignation against monopoly and injustice."George W. E. Russell, ''Collections & Recollections'' (Revised edition, Smith Elder & Co, London, 1899), at page 57. ==Literary career== [[File:Lord Houghton.jpg|thumb|left]] Milnes' literary career was often influenced by church matters. He wrote a tract in 1841, which was praised by [[John Henry Newman]]. He took part in the discussion about "[[Essays and Reviews]]", defending the [[tractarian]] position in ''One Tract More'' (1841). He published two volumes of verse in 1838, ''Memorials of Residence upon the Continent and Poems of Many Years'', ''Poetry for the People'' in 1840 and ''Palm Leaves'' in 1844. He also wrote a ''Life and Letters of Keats'' in 1848, the material for which was largely provided by the poet's friend, [[Charles Armitage Brown]]. Milnes' [[ballad]]s were among the most popular of their day.{{sfn|Saunders|1894}} In 1868, Lord Houghton was elected to the [[Royal Society]].{{cite web |publisher=Royal Society |title=Fellows 1660–2007 |url=https://royalsociety.org/~/media/Royal_Society_Content/about-us/fellowship/Fellows1660-2007.pdf |accessdate=13 June 2016}} In 1870, he was elected a member of the [[American Antiquarian Society]].[http://www.americanantiquarian.org/memberlistm American Antiquarian Society Members Directory] Despite his piety, he had apparently an almost unsurpassed collection of [[erotic literature]],{{cite book | title=A history of pornography | first=Harford Montgomery | last=Hyde | authorlink=H. Montgomery Hyde | publisher=Heinemann | year=1965 | page=14 }} which he bequeathed to the [[British Library]], a collection known to few in his lifetime. A man whom his biographer Saunders said, "had many fine tastes and some coarse ones,"{{sfn|Saunders|1894}} Milnes has been considered a possible author of ''[[The Rodiad]]'', a [[pornography|pornographic]] poem on the subject of [[flagellation]].{{cite book | title=Gendering the nation: studies in modern Scottish literature | first=Christopher | last=Whyte | publisher=Edinburgh University Press | year=1995 | isbn=0-7486-0619-X | page=216 }}{{cite book | first=James G. | last=Nelson | title=Publisher to the Decadents: Leonard Smithers in the Careers of Beardsley, Wilde, Dowson | publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press | year=2000 | isbn=0-271-01974-3 | page=10 }} However, his chief distinctions were his sense of literary merit in others, and the way he fostered it. He was surrounded by the most brilliant men of his time, many of whom he had been the first to acclaim. His reputation rests largely on the part he played, as a man of influence in society and in moulding public opinion on literary matters, in connection with his large circle of talented friends. He secured a pension for [[Alfred Tennyson, 1st Baron Tennyson|Tennyson]], helped to make [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] known in [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]], and was one of the earliest champions of [[Algernon Charles Swinburne]]. He helped [[David Gray (poet)|David Gray]] by writing a preface for ''The Luggie''.{{sfn|Saunders|1894}} He helped to obtain a job for [[Coventry Patmore]] at the [[British Museum]]. He was, in the traditional sense, a patron of literature, who never abused the privileges of his position. He likewise admired the literacy brilliance in female writers and was a firm friend of the [[Elizabeth Gaskell|Gaskell family]] of [[Manchester]]. A believer in the advancement of women, he supported Meta, the daughter of novelist [[Elizabeth Gaskell]] in her work as the Representative of the ''Manchester Ladies' Educational Association'' and on [[The North of England Council for Promoting the Higher Education of Women]]. [[The Spectator]] reported upon Meta's death in 1913 that, "Lord Houghton once said that the conversation and society to be met with in the house of the Gaskells at Manchester – [[84 Plymouth Grove|Plymouth Grove]] – were the one thing which made life in that city tolerable for people of literary tastes".{{cite web|last1=Murray|first1=J. H.|title=The Englishwoman's Review of Social and Industrial Questions: 1872|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=Y4O_DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT112&lpg=PT112&dq=Frances+elizabeth+Lupton+Leeds+Manchester+meta&source=bl&ots=43aSK6enB5&sig=8VyOUhWurzSIcA63z-oIVYBls6k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwinhZ_iv77TAhVCNJQKHVX_ADgQ6AEIJzAB#v=onepage&q=Frances%20elizabeth%20Lupton%20Leeds%20Manchester%20meta&f=false|publisher=Janet Horowitz Murray, Myra Stark |date= 19 December 2016|accessdate=25 April 2017|quote=....Meta Gaskell.... a member of the North of England Council for Education of Woman...}}{{cite web|title=The Englishwoman's Review of Social and Industrial Questions|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=B6FBAQAAMAAJ&q=the+english+woman+manchester+review++frances++lupton+meta&dq=the+english+woman+manchester+review++frances++lupton+meta&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFitvXu77TAhXMj5QKHQs6CzoQ6AEIITAA|publisher=Garland Publishing |year=1985 |origyear= 1874|accessdate=25 April 2014|quote=Josephine E. Butler, President of .......Frances Elizabeth Lupton, Representative of the Leeds Ladies' Educational Association. ... Meta Gaskell, Representative of the Manchester Ladies' Educational Association....Ann J. Clough, Member of Executive...}}{{cite web|title=Miss Meta Gaskell|url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/1st-november-1913/24/miss-meta-gaskell|work=The Spectator |date= 1 November 1913|accessdate=25 April 2017|quote=LORD HOUGHTON once said that the conversation and society to be met with in the house of the Gaskells at Manchester were the one thing which made life in that city tolerable for people of literary tastes. Miss Meta Gaskell, who died last Sunday...}}{{cite web|title=Journal of the Royal Society of Arts, Volume 19|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=bBLyAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA720&dq=manchester+plymouth+grove+Frances+Lupton&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiK8ZCexr7TAhUCpJQKHcUBAP0Q6AEIJTAB#v=onepage&q=manchester%20plymouth%20grove%20Frances%20Lupton&f=false|publisher=The Society |year=1871| pages= 719–720|accessdate=25 April 2014|quote=Announcement by the Council – Education of Girls – The following have agreed to be members of the Committee....Miss Gaskell, Manchester....Mrs Baden-Powell.....Mrs Charles Darwin...Erasmus Darwin Esq...Duchess of St Albans....Mrs Frances Lupton, Leeds....Miss Thackeray.....Henry Sidgwick Esq. Trinity College, Cambridge,...Mrs Kitchener...Miss Emily Davies.....}} ==Personal life== Milnes was a persistent suitor of [[Florence Nightingale]] (who finally refused to marry him), and one of her staunchest supporters along with the statesman [[Sidney Herbert, 1st Baron Herbert of Lea|Sidney Herbert]]. On 30 July 1851, he married the Honourable Annabel, daughter of [[John Crewe, 2nd Baron Crewe]].{{sfn|Saunders|1894}} She died in 1874. Lord Houghton died at [[Vichy]], France, in August 1885, aged 76, and was buried at Fryston. He was succeeded in the barony by his son, [[Robert Crewe-Milnes, 1st Marquess of Crewe|Robert]], who became a prominent Liberal statesman and was created Earl of Crewe in 1895 and [[Marquess of Crewe]] in 1911. The novelist [[Florence Henniker]] was his daughter.{{cite book|last=Pite|first=Ralph|title=Thomas Hardy:The Guarded Life|location=London|publisher=Picador|page=329|year=2006|isbn=978-0330481861}} Milnes took interest in [[parapsychology]], he was a member of the [[Society for Psychical Research]].Oppenheim, Janet. (1988). ''The Other World: Spiritualism and Psychical Research in England, 1850–1914''. Cambridge University Press. p. 135. {{ISBN|978-0521347679}} ==Styles of address== *1809–1837: Mr Richard Monckton Milnes *1837–1863: Mr Richard Monckton Milnes [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|MP]] *1863–1868: ''The Right Honourable'' The Lord Houghton *1868–1885: ''The Right Honourable'' The Lord Houghton [[Royal Society|FRS]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ;Attribution *{{DNB|first=Thomas Bailey|last=Saunders|wstitle=Milnes, Richard Monckton|volume=38|pages= }} *{{EB1911|wstitle=Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron}} == External links == {{Commons category|Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron Houghton}} {{wikiquote}} * {{Hansard-contribs | mr-richard-milnes | Richard Monckton Milnes }} {{S-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Pontefract (UK Parliament constituency)|Pontefract]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 1837|1837]]–[[Pontefract by-election, 1863|1863]] | with = [[William Thomas Stanley-Massey-Stanley]] 1837–1841 | with2 = [[John Savile, 3rd Earl of Mexborough|Viscount Pollington]] 1841–1847 | with3 = [[Samuel Martin (PC)|Samuel Martin]] 1847–1851 | with4 = [[Beilby Lawley, 2nd Baron Wenlock|Beilby Lawley]] 1851–1852 | with5 = [[Benjamin Oliveira]] 1852–1857 | with6 = [[William Wood (MP for Pontefract)|William Wood]] 1857–1859 | with7 = [[William Overend]] 1859–1860 | with8 = [[Hugh Childers]] 1860–1863 | before = [[John Gully]]
[[John Savile, 3rd Earl of Mexborough|Viscount Pollington]] | after = [[Hugh Childers]]
[[Samuel Waterhouse]] }} {{s-reg|uk}} {{s-new | creation}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Marquess of Crewe|Baron Houghton]] | years = 1863–1885 }} {{s-aft | after = [[Robert Crewe-Milnes, 1st Marquess of Crewe|Robert Offley Ashburton Crewe-Milnes]] }} {{S-end}} {{Royal Statistical Society presidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron}} [[Category:1809 births]] [[Category:1885 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Members of The Club]] [[Category:Presidents of the Royal Statistical Society]] [[Category:Barons in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Parapsychologists]] [[Category:Patrons of literature]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) MPs for English constituencies]] [[Category:UK MPs 1837–41]] [[Category:UK MPs 1841–47]] [[Category:UK MPs 1847–52]] [[Category:UK MPs 1852–57]] [[Category:UK MPs 1857–59]] [[Category:UK MPs 1859–65]] [[Category:Bibliophiles]] [[Category:English male poets]] [[Category:19th-century English poets]] [[Category:Members of the American Antiquarian Society]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=December 2010}} {{Notability|1=Music|date=August 2014}} }}
[[File:Sheila Nicholls in shadow.jpg|thumb|Sheila Nicholls in 2014]] '''Sheila Elizabeth Nicholls''' (born 9 February 1970 in [[Colchester]], Essex) is a British singer-songwriter, now residing in [[Highland Park, Los Angeles|Highland Park]], Los Angeles, California.
==Early years== While growing up, Nicholls attended [[Felsted School]]. She first found fame for performing [[Cartwheel (gymnastics)|cartwheels]] while [[streaking]] at an [[England cricket team|England]] vs. [[Australia cricket team|Australia]] [[cricket]] match at [[Lord's]] in May 1989, in which she joined fellow school players [[Derek Pringle]] and [[John Stephenson (cricketer, born 1965)|John Stephenson]] on the field of play;<ref>{{cite news|title=Streaker Sheila sneaks a bare run|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=J001AAAAIBAJ&sjid=pKULAAAAIBAJ&pg=6414,2637812&dq=sheila+nicholls+streaker&hl=en|accessdate=24 December 2010|newspaper=[[Glasgow Herald]]|date=30 May 1989|page=3}}</ref> this footage was later included in the video ''Streaker'', narrated by [[George Best]].
Nicholls travelled to the United States later in 1989 and began performing with her band, Sheila Nicholls and the Splendid Frock, in New York City in the mid-1990s.
==Critical acclaim== Nicholls then moved to Los Angeles where she recorded a solo album, the critically acclaimed ''Brief Strop'' (1999),<ref>{{cite news|title=All flavors, all finds|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CGMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA116|accessdate=24 December 2010|newspaper=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=20 June 2000|page=116}}</ref> and started her own label, Essex Girl Records.
Shortly thereafter, Nicholls signed a deal with [[Hollywood Records]], which began distributing ''Brief Strop''. The song "Fallen for You," from the album, became a hit on [[Campus radio|college radio]] stations and found its way onto the best-selling soundtrack for the movie [[High Fidelity (film)|High Fidelity]]. She toured extensively with the album, including several gigs alongside [[k.d. lang]].
"After some moral deliberations about taking [[Criticism of The Walt Disney Company#General criticism|Disney blood money]]... I negotiated a deal in which I asked for final creative say across the board and the full ownership of my master copies, both of which I got."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Protest songs: Record labels aren't listening [Blowback]|url = http://opinion.latimes.com/opinionla/2011/12/protest-songs-occupyla-sheila-nicholls-blowback.html|accessdate = 17 August 2015}}</ref>
In mid-2002, Nicholls released her second album, ''Wake'', in which she worked with producers [[Glen Ballard]] and [[The Latin Project|Jez Colin]]. The album's first single, "Faith," co-written with Ballard, received ample radio play and reached the pop charts. Nicholls third album, "Songs From the Bardo" was released in August 2009. "After releasing two albums with Hollywood Records, I decided to lay low for a minute. I built a studio, bought equipment, and taught myself [[Pro Tools|ProTools]]. I really wanted to expand my abilities and have more creative independence. Consequently this record took a while because I did it myself, with some help from friends. Oh and I also had a baby."<ref>{{Cite web|title = New Music Sheila Nicholls + free downloads|url = https://extramusicnew.wordpress.com/2010/05/28/new-music-sheila-nicholls-free-downloads/|accessdate = 17 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2013 Sheila Nichols was approached by singer, songwriter, executive producer and former Navy SEAL Curt Campbell asking her if she would be interested in recording an album of original material. Hence the emergence of her 4th album "All of Nature" which was released in 2016.
==Personal life==
Sheila has one daughter, born in 2007.
In 2011 she spent two months with [[Occupy Los Angeles]], camping outside [[Los Angeles City Hall|City Hall]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Protest songs: Record labels aren't listening [Blowback]|url = http://opinion.latimes.com/opinionla/2011/12/protest-songs-occupyla-sheila-nicholls-blowback.html|accessdate = 17 August 2015}}</ref> and appearing in NPR's coverage.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Battle Cry: Occupy's Messaging Tactics Catch On|url = https://www.npr.org/2011/12/06/142999617/battle-cry-occupys-messaging-tactics-catch-on|publisher = NPR|accessdate = 17 August 2015|first = Carrie Kahn Twitter Facebook|last = Tumblr}}</ref>
==Discography== *''Brief Strop'' **Released: 16 November 1999, Label: Essex Girl # "Question' (3:53) # "Elevator" (4:19) # "Hannah" (5:15) # "Eiderdown" (4:20) # "Fallen For You" (3:16) # "Peanuts" (5:34) # "Don't Die on the Vine" (3:50) # "Medusa" (3:38) # "Patience" (3:09) # "Perfection" (4:22) # "War Isn't Working" (2:17) # "So One Day" (2:32) # "Rapunzel" (3:32) # "Pan" (3:41)
*''Wake'' **Released: 14 May 2002, Label: Essex Girl # "How Strong" (4:23) # "Bread and Water" (4:39) # "Faith" (4:12) # "Love Song" (4:23) # "Maze" (3:50) # "Ruby" (2:51) # "Moth and the Streetlight" (4:43) # "Seven Fat Englishmen" (3:59) # "Won't Get Lost In You" (3:32) # "Come To Me" (3:23) # "Breath" (4:20) # "Ownership" (hidden track)
*''Ode To Britney'' (4:41) **Released: 8 May 2008 *''Songs from the Bardo'' **Released: August 2009, Label: Essex Girl # "Where None are Afraid" (3:48) # "Pinking Up" (3:57) # "Bardo" (4:32) # "Old Friend" (3:18) # "Natural Law" (3:44) # "Pointless Tackles Vision" (5:03) # "Mighty Love" (3:26) # "Celery Bay" (4:19) # "City Between" (3:20) # "Bed" (3:44) # "Lay Low" (4:36) # "Simplify" (4:04)

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji }} {{Infobox Hindu leader | name =Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj | image =Spsksjm.jpg | image_size =320x320px | alt = | caption = <!-- titled displayed below that image --> | birth_name = <!-- --> | birth_date = <!-- -->5 September 1943 | birth_place =[[India]] | nationality = [[India]]n | spouse = <!-- Name(s) of spouse(s), years of marriage: {{marriage|Name|year married|year separated}} --> | children = <!-- Number of children (e.g., 3), or list of children names --> | relatives = <!-- Names of parents, siblings or other relatives. --> | honors = | sect = <!-- Sects/Traditions associated with the Hindu leader--> [[Advait Mat]] | order = | guru = <!-- His or her teacher (if any), should be supported by a citation from a reliable source --> | philosophy = <!-- Preferably one that has a wikipedia page --> [[Rāja yoga|Rajyoga]], [[Advaita Vedanta]], [[Bhakti yoga]], [[Karma yoga]] | literary_works = <!-- Preferably having pages on wikipedia and wikisource--> | disciple = <!-- Prominent disciple(s) only --> | known_for = <!-- Why the person is notable (as discussed in main article with reliable sources) --> [http://satyarthiji.com/ Paramhans Satyarthi Mission] (Shri Nangli Sahib) | influenced = <!-- People the Hindu leader influenced (as mentioned in main article) --> | signature = <!--Preferably uploaded on wikipedia commons--> | signature_alt = | module = <!-- Used for embedding other templates --> | free_label = | free_text = | footnotes = }}
'''Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj''' (''Hindi'': श्री स्वामी केशवानन्द सत्यार्थी जी महाराज) is an [[India]]n [[Guru]]. The spiritual institution '''Paramhans Satyarthi Mission''' is led and governed by him. He is one of the major saints of '''Shri Nangli Sahib'''. He was born as younger son of Shri Paramhans Swami Ramanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj (1897-1986). Shri Paramhans Swami Ramanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj founded Paramhans Satyarthi Mission and in 1985 he anointed Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj as his spiritual successor and the patron saint of the Paramhans Satyarthi Mission.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Shri Swarup Darshan|last=Sri Swami Sar|first=Shabdanand Ji|publisher=Sar Shabd Mission|year=1998|isbn=|location=New Delhi, India|pages=601–654}}</ref> Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj travels around the world and preaches about spirituality and enlightenment. He is also the koshadhyaksh (treasurer) of Shri Nangli Sahib Guru Mandir Trust. Swami Ramanand Satyarthi Trust, Shri Satyarthi Sevadal, Shri Satyarthi High School, and ''Shri Satyarthi Sandesh Magazine'' are also administered in his guidance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://events.sulekha.com/hindu-temple-of-washington-presents-unique-experience-of-spiritual-enlightenment-by-swami-keshwanand-satyarthi-ji_event-in_hyattsville-md_288114|title=Hindu Temple of Washington Presents Unique experience of spiritual enlightenment by Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji|last=|first=|date=2013|work=Sulekha|access-date=}}</ref>
== Life == He was born on 5 September 1943, in a religious family and was named as Shri Khairati Lal Bhardwaj. His father, Pandit Khushiram Bhardwaj was a devotee of Lord [[Krishna]] and was a scholar of [[Sanskrit]], [[Astrology]], [[Vedanta|Vedenta]], Shastras and [[Upanishads]]. Pandit Khushiram Bhardwaj Ji became a disciple of [[Swarupanand|Swami Swarupanand Ji Maharaj]] and adopted a life of renunciation ([[Sannyasa|Sanyas]]). He was later famed as Shri Swami Ramanand Satyarthi ji Maharaj.
Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj acquired knowledge of Rajyoga from Shri Swami Ramanand Satyarthi ji Maharaj. By the age of ten years he used to go into state of super-consciousness ([[Samadhi]]) with ease. He continued his practices of Raj Yoga with his schooling and graduation. He also holds a degree of M.A.
[[Advaitanand Ji|Shri Swami Advaitanand Ji Maharaj]] (1846-1919) also known as the "First Spiritual Master" of the Shri Paramhans Advait Mat lineage, initiated the "Second Spiritual Master", [[Swarupanand|Swami Swarupanand Ji Maharaj]] ( also known as Shri Nangli Niwasi Bhagwan Ji) in the early 1900s. Swami Swarupanand Ji Maharaj was further succeeded by Shri Swami Paramhans Ramanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Shri Paramhansa Advait Mat: A life sketch of the Illustrious Master of the Mat|last=|first=|publisher=Shri Anandpur Trust|year=1975|isbn=|location=India|pages=145–146}}</ref> On 2 July 1985(the day Vyas Pooja), Shri Swami Ramanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj declared Shri Khairati Lal Bhardwaj as his spiritual successor and the patron saint of Paramhans Satyarthi Mission and named him as Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sarshabdmission.com/our-gurus/shri-swami-swarupanand-ji/|title=Favour Granted to Satyarthi Ji|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj adopted renunciation (Sanyas) and vowed to publicize the supreme knowledge of Paramhans tradition on 8 January 1995 at Satyarthi Samadhi Mandir, Shri Nangli Sahib. Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj has founded various Satyarthi Dhams ([[Ashram]]s) at [[New Delhi]], [[Haridwar]], [[Lucknow]], [[Chhatarpur metro station|Chhatarpur]], [[Bareilly|Bareily]] and [[Raipur Nangli|Shri Nangli Sahib]]. Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj organizes Gyan-Yagyas at different places.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.jagran.com/uttar-pradesh/muzaffarnagar-12404451.html|title=मुजफ्फरनगर : श्री परमहंस सत्यार्थी मिशन द्वारा सनातन धर्म सभा भवन में सत्यार्थी ज्ञान यज्ञ हुआ।|last=|first=|date=25 May 2015|work=Jagran|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://m.dailyhunt.in/news/bangladesh/hindi/uttar+pradesh-epaper-uttar/sansarik+sukh+kshanik+anubhuti+hai+satyarthi-newsid-88862726|title=सांसारिक सुख क्षणिक अनुभूति है: सत्यार्थी|last=|first=|date=29 May 2018|work=Daily Hunt|access-date=}}</ref> Paramhans Satyarthi Mission organizes camps for spiritual and moral understanding every year at Rajyog Mandir, New Delhi in which Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj teaches the practices of [[Dhyana in Hinduism|Dhyana]] and meditation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bhaskar.com/punjab/jalandhar/news/PUN-JAL-OMC-MAT-latest-jalandhar-news-032526-2827860-NOR.html|title=हर श्वास नंगली वालों के नाम संध्या|date=2015-10-12|work=dainikbhaskar|access-date=2018-04-27|language=hi}}</ref>
== Primary teachings == The primary teachings of Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj are [[Bhakti]], Sewa(Service), Prem (love) and [[Rāja yoga]] (meditation). The spiritual institution (Paramhans Satyarthi Mission) led by Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj believes in the principle of Vasudev Kutumbkam. The symbol of the mission is Hans or the [[swan]] bird on the lotus flower. "Satya" (truth) is the methodology of the mission. Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj preaches the concept and relevance of [[Advaita Vedanta]] and self-realization. Advait refers to its idea that the soul ([[Ātman (Hinduism)|Atman]]) is the same as the highest metaphysical Reality ([[Brahman]]). Advaita Vedanta emphasizes the idea that ''[[moksha]]'' is achievable in this life in contrast to Indian philosophies that emphasize moksha after death. Advaita Vedanta is one of the most studied and most influential schools of classical Indian thought. Advaita philosophy is non-dualistic.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://satyarthiji.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=featured&Itemid=435|title=Paramhans Satyarthi Mission|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://m.bhaskar.com/news/HAR-SONI-MAT-latest-sonipat-news-032026-3035387-NOR.html|title=Focus on family solidarity rather than money|last=|first=|date=2015-11-17|work=Dainik Bhaskar|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Raj yoga === Raj yoga is variously referred to as "royal yoga", "royal union", "sahaj marg", "best of yoga". Raj yoga refers to the goal of yoga (which is usually [[samadhi]]). Raja Yoga meditation is an inwardly oriented practice. Shri Swami Keshwanand Satyarthi Ji Maharaj teaches the way to meditate on the pious name which is two and a half words powerful [[mantra]]. This mantra is given to the devotees as Updesh. It is known to make the person’s life free of all hassles, to show and guide him in the right direction. He has written several books on Rajyog, Sewa, Satya, etc.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://navbharattimes.indiatimes.com/state/uttar-pradesh/ghaziabad/quotthe-conquest-of-disorders-meet-god-39/articleshow/16645919.cms|title='विकारों पर विजय से मिलेंगे भगवान'|last=|first=|date=Oct 3, 2012|work=Navbharat times|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Sewa === In his view, sewa is the best way of practicing Bhakti. It could be in any way, by going to his temple and physically contributing to the activities happening there, by remembering him in our hearts and doing Pooja (worship) at home, by devoting (as per the wish) to the funds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bhaskar.com/punjab/jalandhar/news/PUN-JAL-OMC-MAT-latest-jalandhar-news-032526-2827860-NOR.html|title=माता-पिता बच्चों को गोसेवा के संस्कार दें|last=|first=|date=2016|work=Dainik Bhaskar|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Bhakti === Bhakti means devotion. [[Bhakti yoga]] means to practice connecting the God, and establishing our relationship with, God, through acts of love and service, or devotional service. Basic principle of Bhakti-yoga, or devotional service, is that the Absolute Truth is not an impersonal void but rather the Supreme Person. The goal of one who practices Bhakti yoga is to revive that state of pure consciousness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.jagran.com/uttar-pradesh/muzaffarnagar-13780637.html|title=Satyarthi Seva Dal- Knowledge Yajna in Sanatan Dharma Sabha|last=|first=|date=28 Mar 2016|work=Jagran|access-date=}}</ref>

{{Use Indian English|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{refimprove|date=August 2017}} {{tone|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Thakkar Bapa | image = | caption = | birth_name = Amritlal Vithaldas Thakkar | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1869|11|29}} | birth_place = [[Bhavnagar]], [[Gujarat]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1951|1|20|1869|11|29|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality = [[demographics of India|Indian]] | education = [[L.C.E.]] ([[Licenciate in Civil Engineering]], presently equivalent to [[Graduate in Civil Engineering]]) | occupation = Social worker | spouse = | children = | signature = }} '''Amritlal Vithaldas Thakkar''', popularly known as '''Thakkar Bapa''' (29 November 1869 – 20 January 1951) was an Indian [[social worker]] who worked for upliftment of tribal people in [[Gujarat]] state in [[India]]. He became a member of the [[Servants of India Society]] founded by [[Gopal Krishna Gokhale]] in 1914.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2006/20060603/edit.htm#14|title=Thakkar Bapa – Friend of poor |date=3 June 2006|publisher=[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]|accessdate=30 December 2009|location=Chandigarh}}</ref> In 1922, he founded the ''Bhil Seva Mandal''. Later, he became the general secretary of the ''[[Harijan Sevak Sangh]]'' founded by [[Mahatma Gandhi]] in 1932 .<ref name="Revankar1971">{{cite book|author=Ratna G. Revankar|title=The Indian Constitutions --: A Case Study of Backward Classes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ukZRZk_ttYcC&pg=PA124|date=1 January 1971|publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press|isbn=978-0-8386-7670-7|pages=124–}}</ref> The ''Bharatiya Adimjati Sevak Sangh'' was founded on 24 October 1948 on his initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bajss.com/index.html|title=Bharatiya Adimjati Sevak Sangh (BAJSS) – Introduction|publisher=Bharatiya Adimjati Sevak Sangh website|accessdate=30 December 2009}}</ref> When Indian constitution was in process, Thakkarbapa visited remotest and most difficult parts of India and conducted probe into the situation of tribal and [[Harijan]] people. He added valuable inputs{{which|date=August 2017}} in the process of constitution. Mahatma Gandhi would call him 'Bapa'.
Thakkarbapa visited forests in Assam, rural Bengal, drought affected areas of Orissa, Bhil belts in Gujarat and Harijan areas of Saurashtra, Mahar areas of Maharashtra, untouchables in Madras, hilly areas of Chhota Nagpur, desert of Tharparkar, foothills of Himalaya, coastal areas of [[Travancore]] with his mission of upliftment of tribal and harijans. He would always travel in third class of railway. Thakkarbapa spent 35 years of his life in service of tribal and harijans.
== Early life == Thakkar Bappa was born on 29 November 1869 in a middle-class family of [[Bhavnagar]] in Saurashtra region of Gujarat State India. His father Vithal Das Thakkar named the child Amrit Lal. He received his first schooling for benevolence and service to humanity from his father. He got his L.C.E. (Licenciate in Civil Engineering) from Poona in 1890. He worked as an engineer creditably in Porbander and later went out of India to serve in laying the First Railway Track in Uganda (East Africa). He served also as chief engineer in Sangli State for some time and then was employed in Bombay municipality as an engineer. It was here he saw, for the first time, the miserable conditions of those scavengers who had to dispose of the refuse of the whole town of Bombay. He was shocked to see the filthy colonies where the Sweepers had to live and made a firm resolve to devote the rest of his life to alleviate the lot of these people. He later served in Uganda (Country) railways in East Africa. In 1914, he resigned and took up social work. He became a member of Servants of India Society and advocated the rights of untouchables and tribals.
== Honors == The [[Government of India]] issued a stamp in his honour in 1969. A well known locality, [[Bappa Colony]] in [[Mumbai]] is named after him. The [[Madhya Pradesh]] state government has instituted an award named in his honour for dedicated services to poor, victimised and totally backward tribal community.Maharashtra government has set the scheme to improve aadivasi villages and colonies named Thakkar Bappa aadivasi vasti sudharana in the year 2007
== Popular culture == In [[Tamil Nadu]], Thakkar was popularly known as "Appa Thakkar", the [[Tamil language|Tamil]] version of "Thakkar Bapa". Due to the fact that he was very knowledgeable, often instantly answering questions thrown at him, the [[Madras Bashai]] term "appatakkar", meaning a [[Know-it-all|know-all]], developed.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tnsxZaruv0U |title=Who is Appatakkar |last=Gowri |first=Madan |date=15 November 2017 |website=YouTube |language=ta |access-date=4 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title='Tamil is semma gethu language machi' |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/Tamil-is-semma-gethu-language-machi/articleshow/50884605.cms |accessdate=4 June 2018 |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=7 February 2016}}</ref> This term gained popularity through its usage in the 2010 Tamil film ''[[Boss Engira Bhaskaran]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Balachandran |first1=Logesh |title=Therikavidalama to Senjiduven: Quirky K'wood dialogues |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Therikavidalama-to-Senjiduven-Quirky-Kwood-dialogues/articleshow/49337190.cms |accessdate=4 June 2018 |work=The Times of India}}</ref>

'''Tomas Bjäringer''' HFRPSL is a Swedish [[philatelist]] who was added to the [[Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] in 1978.<ref name=abps>''[http://www.abps.org.uk/Awards/Roll_of_Distinguished_Philatelists/RDP_Background_20111231_LR.pdf Background notes on The Roll of Distinguished Philatelists September 2011]'', Roll of Distinguished Philatelists Trust, London, 2011. [https://www.webcitation.org/6OlHSBOTl Archived here.]</ref>
Bjäringer is the [[Royal Philatelic Society London]]'s special representative for France.<ref>[http://www.rpsl.org.uk/society_representatives.asp County & Country Representatives.] Royal Philatelic Society London. Retrieved 23 March 2015.</ref> He is a specialist in the philately of Sweden, particularly the [[Philatelic fakes and forgeries|fakes and forgeries]] of that country. He also collects early [[philatelic literature]]. Bjäringer is a director of the Ringström Museum för Filateli.<ref>[http://www.ringphilmuseum.se/eng_styrelse.html Board of Directors and Auditors.] Ringström Museum för Filateli. Retrieved 23 March 2015.</ref>
==Selected publications== *''Vad Portot kan Berätta om Brevens Väg: Demonstration av Några Långväga Försändelser''. Stockholm: Tomas Bjäringer, 1969. *''Swedish letter rates to foreign destinations 1855-1895''. Trelleborg: Skogs boktr., cop. 1986. (With Jan Billgren, Louis H Stone, Yngve Hellström, Vello Kallas.)

{{Infobox person | name = Tricia Raikes | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Co-founder, co-president of the [[Raikes Foundation]] | years_active = | net_worth = | boards = College Success Foundation,
Jeffrey S. Raikes School of Computer Science and Management at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln | religion = | spouse = [[Jeff Raikes]] | children = Michaela, Connor, and Gillian | parents = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = http://raikesfoundation.org/tricia-raikes }} '''Tricia Raikes''' is an American businesswoman and philanthropist. She is the co-founder and co-president of the Raikes Foundation, and has held this position since 2002.{{Cite web|url=http://raikesfoundation.org/tricia-raikes|title=Tricia Raikes|website=Raikes Foundation|access-date=2016-03-16}}{{cite web|title=White House to honor Wisconsin man as ‘Champion of Change’|url=http://wisconsingazette.com/2012/07/10/white-house-to-honor-wisconsin-man-as-champion-of-change/|website=Wisconsin Gazette|accessdate=3 April 2016}} Her husband is [[Jeff Raikes]], former CEO of the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]].{{cite web|last1=Payne|first1=Patti|title=Raikes Foundation receives major award for its work to end youth homelessness in King County|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/blog/2014/10/raikes-foundation-receives-major-award-for-its.html|website=Puget Sound Business Journal|accessdate=3 April 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Todd|first1=Leah|title=Robert Craves co-founded Costco, nonprofit that sent thousands to college dies at 72|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/robert-craves-co-founded-costco-nonprofit-that-sent-thousands-to-college-dies-at-72/|website=[[Seattle Times]]|accessdate=3 April 2016}} == Career == Prior to co-founding the Raikes Foundation, Tricia was Director of Creative Services and Marketing Communications at [[Microsoft]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/tricia-raikes-31715418?authType=NAME_SEARCH&authToken=IykY&locale=en_US&trk=tyah&trkInfo=clickedVertical%253Amynetwork%252CclickedEntityId%253A60079555%252CauthType%253ANAME_SEARCH%252Cidx%253A1-1-1%252CtarId%253A1458097887453%252Ctas%253Atricia%2520raikes|title=Tricia Raikes {{!}} LinkedIn|website=www.linkedin.com|access-date=2016-03-16}} Tricia holds a position on the Board of Directors for the [[College Success Foundation]] for Washington DC and Washington State.{{Cite web|url=http://www.collegesuccessfoundation.org/about-us/board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors - About Us - College Success Foundation|website=www.collegesuccessfoundation.org|access-date=2016-03-16}} Additionally, Tricia serves on the Board of Directors for the [[Jeffrey S. Raikes School|Jeffrey S. Raikes School of Computer Science and Management]] with her husband, [[Jeff Raikes]].{{Cite web|url=http://raikes.unl.edu/school/advisorbio/2|title=Jeffrey S. Raikes School of Computer Science and Management|last=Network|first=University of Nebraska-Lincoln {{!}} Web Developer|website=raikes.unl.edu|access-date=2016-03-16}} Tricia has held other leadership roles, working with Stanford University’s Task Force on Undergraduate Education, and serving the United Way of King County as the co-chair of their 2006-2007 campaign.{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/champions/fighting-youth-homelessness/tricia-raikes|title=Tricia raikes|website=The White House|access-date=2016-03-16}} Additionally, Tricia has served on boards for the Washington State University Foundation and the King County Boys & Girls Club. Tricia has been recognized as one of the [[Puget Sound Business Journal]]'s Women of Influence in 2007,{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/special/2015/PSBJwomenofinfluence/Alumnae#2007|title=The Business Journals - Puget Sound Business Journal|website=Puget Sound Business Journal|access-date=2016-03-16}} named the 2012 [[ParentMap Newsmagazine|ParentMap]] Humanitarian Superhero,{{Cite web|url=https://www.parentmap.com/article/2012-superheroes-for-washington-families?page=2|title=2012 Superheroes for Washington Families - ParentMap|website=www.parentmap.com|access-date=2016-03-16}} and selected as one of the White House's Champions of Change for her work addressing youth homelessness. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://raikesfoundation.org/ Raikes Foundation] [[Category:Philanthropists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Microsoft people]] [[Category:Women philanthropists]] [[Category:American philanthropists]]

{{Otheruses4|the Cheyenne chief|other uses|Two Moons (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox American Indian chief | name = Two Moon | image = Two Moons Cheyenne Chief.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Two Moon (Credit: [[Northwestern University Library]] [http://digital.library.northwestern.edu/curtis/ ''Edward S. Curtis's The North American Indian,'' 2003]). | tribe = [[Cheyenne people|Cheyenne]] | lead = | birth_date = 1847 | birth_place = [[Montana]] | death_date = 1917 | death_place = | predecessor = | successor = | native_name = Ishaynishus, Éše'he Ôhnéšesêstse | nicknames = | known_for = Participation in the [[Battle of the Rosebud]], [[Battle of Little Big Horn]], and the [[Battle of Wolf Mountain]]; [[United States Army Indian Scouts|Indian Scout]]; Chief of the [[Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation|Cheyenne Northern Reservation]] | death_cause = | resting_place = Alongside [[U.S. Route 212]], west of [[Busby, Montana]] | rp_coordinates = | religion = | party = | education = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = Father, Carries the Otter | relations = | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Two Moons''' (1847–1917), or ''Ishaynishus'' ([[Cheyenne language|Cheyenne]]: ''Éše'he Ôhnéšesêstse''),<ref>[http://www.cdkc.edu/cheyennedictionary/index-english/main.htmm Cheyenne Dictionary]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by Fisher, Leman, Pine, Sanchez.</ref> was one of the Cheyenne chiefs who took part in the [[Battle of the Little Bighorn]] and other battles against the United States Army.<ref>Curtis, E. (1907) [http://curtis.library.northwestern.edu/ ''The North American Indian. Vol.6 The Piegan, the Cheyenne and the Arapaho''.].</ref>
==Life== Two Moons was the son of Carries the Otter, an [[Arikara]] captive who married into the [[Cheyenne]] tribe. Perhaps known best for his participation in battles such as the [[Battle of the Rosebud]] against [[George Crook|General Crook]] on June 17, 1876, in the [[Montana Territory]], the [[Battle of Little Big Horn]] on June 25, 1876 and what would prove to be his last battle, the [[Battle of Wolf Mountain]] on January 8, 1877. Two Moons' defeat in the battle at Wolf mountain by [[Nelson A. Miles|General Nelson A. Miles]] would inevitably lead to the surrender of his Cheyenne band at [[Fort Keogh]] in April, 1877.<ref>Hardorff, Richard G. Indian Views of the Custer Fight. University of Oklahoma Press 2005, p.107</ref>
After the surrender of the Cheyenne band he led in 1877, Two Moons chose to enlist as an [[United States Army Indian Scouts|Indian Scout]] for the same General, Nelson A. Miles to whom he had not long since surrendered. As a result of Two Moons' pleasant personality, the friendliness that he showed towards the [[White American|whites]] as well as his ability to get along with the military, General Miles appointed him head Chief of the [[Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation|Cheyenne Northern Reservation]]. As head Chief, Two Moons would prove to play a crucial role in facilitating the surrender of Chief Little Cow's Cheyenne band to [[Fort Keogh]].<ref>Garland, Hamlin. Account of The Battle at Little Bighorn (Recalled in 1898 by Two Moons). [[McClure's|McClure's Magazine]], 1898</ref>
==Northern Cheyenne Reservation== [[file:Indian Head Buffalo Obverse.jpg | thumb | left |Two Moons was one of the models for the [[Buffalo nickel]].]] Two Moons traveled on multiple occasions to [[Washington, D.C.]], to discuss and fight for the future of the Northern Cheyenne people and to better the conditions that existed on the reservation. In 1914, Two Moons met with President [[Woodrow Wilson]] to discuss these matters.
Two Moons was one of the models selected for [[James Earle Fraser (sculptor)|James Fraser]]'s famous [[Buffalo Nickel]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Bowers | first = Q. David | authorlink = Q. David Bowers | year = 2007 | title = A Guide Book of Buffalo and Jefferson Nickels | publisher = Whitman Publishing | location = Atlanta, Ga. | pages = 38–39 | isbn = 978-0-7948-2008-4 | ref = harv }}</ref> {{clear}}
==Death== Two Moons died in 1917 at his home in [[Montana]] at the age of 70. Two Moons' grave still lies alongside [[U.S. Route 212]], west of [[Busby, Montana]].<ref>Hatch, Thom. The Custer Companion. Stackpole Books 2002, p. 221, 222</ref>
==References== <references /> *Time Life Books. (1993). The Wild West. Time Life Books. *Richard G. Hardorff, ''Cheyenne memories of the Custer fight'', University of Nebraska Press, 1998 {{ISBN|0-8032-7311-8}}.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Two Moons}} [[Category:Native American leaders]] [[Category:Cheyenne people]] [[Category:People of the Great Sioux War of 1876]] [[Category:1847 births]] [[Category:1917 deaths]] [[Category:People of pre-statehood Montana]] [[Category:Burials in Montana]] [[Category:Battle of the Little Bighorn]]

revision.text:
'''Tyler Colman''', writing under the pen name '''Dr. Vino''', is an [[United States|American]] [[author]] with a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in [[political science]] from [[Northwestern University]],<ref name=wofw-ws>{{cite web |last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''The World of Fine Wine'' |title= Everyone a Critic. The Future of Wine Writing |url= http://www.finewinemag.com/docs/SteinbergerWineWriting.pdf |date= March 2008 |format= PDF |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519182406/http://www.finewinemag.com/docs/SteinbergerWineWriting.pdf |archivedate= 2011-05-19 |df= }}</ref> and [[wine]] educator with the [[New York University]] and the [[University of Chicago]], and publisher of one of the internet's most highly rated wine [[blog]]s,<ref name=f&w-blogs>{{Cite web|last= Butts |first= Mickey, ''Food & Wine'' | url=http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/seven-best-wine-blogs |title=Seven Best Wine Blogs | date= October 2005 }}</ref><ref name=fc-blogs>{{Cite web|last= Pollack |first= Jennifer, ''Fast Company'' | url=http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/105/next-best-blogs.html |title=Off the Vine, Now Online | date= May 2006 }}</ref> which won the Best Wine Blog and Best Wine Blog writing in the 2007 American Wine Blog Awards<ref>Fermentation.typepad.com (February 21, 2007) [http://fermentation.typepad.com/fermentation/2007/02/american_wine_b_4.html American Wine Blog Awards Winners]</ref> and was nominated for a James Beard Foundation award.<ref>JamesBeard.org (May 6, 2007) [http://www.jamesbeard.org/index.php?q=awards/show/Tzo4OiJzdGRDbGFzcyI6Mzp7czo4OiJjYXRlZ29yeSI7czoxMDoiSm91cm5hbGlzbSI7czo0OiJ5ZWFyIjtzOjQ6IjIwMDciO3M6NToiYXdhcmQiO3M6NjA6IldlYnNpdGUgRm9jdXNpbmcgb24gRm9vZCwgQmV2ZXJhZ2UsIFJlc3RhdXJhbnQsIG9yIE51dHJpdGlvbiI7fQ== Website Focusing on Food, Beverage, Restaurant, or Nutrition]</ref> A Forbes.com story quoted one expert describing DrVino.com: "His reporting over the past six months has had seismic consequences, which is a hell of an accomplishment for a blog."<ref name=forbes>{{Cite web|last= Arnold |first= Eric, ''Forbes.com'' | url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/10/23/wine-blogs-best-lifestyle-wine-vaynerchuk.html |title=Must-Read Wine Blogs | date= October 23, 2009 }}</ref>
Colman's articles have also appeared in publications that include ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name=nytdrv>{{cite web|last= Colman |first= Tyler, ''The New York Times'' |title= Red, White or Green? |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/30/opinion/30CTcolman.html |date= December 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=nytdrv2>{{cite web|last= Colman |first= Tyler, ''The New York Times'' |title= Drink Outside the Box |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/18/opinion/18colman.html |date= August 18, 2008 }}</ref> ''[[Food & Wine]]'',<ref name=f&w>{{cite web|last= Colman |first= Tyler, ''Food & Wine'' |title= Finding Wine of a Certain Age |url= http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/finding-wine-of-a-certain-age |date= July 2007 }}</ref><ref name=f&w2>{{cite web|last= Colman |first= Tyler, ''Food & Wine'' |title= Deconstructing a Wine List |url= http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/deconstructing-a-wine-list |date= June 2006 }}</ref> ''[[Forbes#Forbes.com|Forbes.com]]'',<ref name=forb>{{cite web|last= Colman |first= Tyler, ''Forbes.com'' |title= Seriously, Drink Beaujolais |url= https://www.forbes.com/2009/08/13/beaujolais-red-wine-lifestyle-wine-summer-drinking.html |date= August 13, 2009 }}</ref> and ''[[Wine & Spirits]]''. In September 2008, a Colman article on wine politics featured in the expert guide ''[[The Guardian]] & [[The Observer]] Guide to Wine''.<ref name=gua-tc>{{cite web|last= Colman |first= Tyler, ''The Guardian'' |title= The decision-makers |url= https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/sep/06/63 |date= September 6, 2008 }}</ref>
The University of California Press published Colman's first book, ''Wine Politics: How Governments, Environmentalists, Mobsters, and Critics Influence the Wines We Drink'' in July 2008. Simon & Schuster published his second book, ''A Year of Wine: Perfect Pairings, Great Buys, and What to Sip for Each Season'' in November 2008. Colman is among the contributors to ''[[The Oxford Companion to Wine]]'' since the third edition. He has also co-authored with sustainability metrics specialist Pablo Päster a widely cited study on the [[carbon footprint]] of wine, for the American Association of Wine Economists.<ref name= wofw-ws/><ref>The American Association of Wine Economists {{cite web|url= http://www.wine-economics.org/workingpapers/AAWE_WP09.pdf |title=Red, White and "Green": The Cost of Carbon in the Global Wine Trade }} {{small|(197 KB)}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of wine personalities]]
==References== {{refbegin}} *[http://www.ucpress.edu/books/pages/10762.php ''Wine Politics'' and Tyler Colman profile] UCpress.edu {{refend}} ;Footnotes {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.drvino.com/ Dr. Vino blog]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Colman, Tyler}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Wine critics]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Winthrop Ames.jpg|thumb|right|Winthrop Ames]] '''Winthrop Ames''' (November 25, 1870 – November 3, 1937) was an [[United States|American]] theatre [[Theatre director|director]] and [[Theatrical producer|producer]], [[playwright]] and [[screenwriter]].
For three decades at the beginning of the 20th century, Ames was an important force on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], whose repertoire included directing and producing Shakespeare and classic plays, new plays, and revivals of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s [[Savoy opera]]s.
==Biography== Ames was born in [[Easton, Massachusetts|North Easton]], [[Massachusetts]] to Cathrine Hobart and [[Oakes Angier Ames]], members of a wealthy manufacturing family.<ref>[http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss358_bioghist.html "Ames Family Papers, 1812-2008"], Biographical Notes, Five Colleges Archives and Manuscript Collections</ref> Ames studied art and architecture at [[Harvard University]]. He worked in the publishing business before turning to a career in the theatre. In 1911, Ames married Lucy (Fuller) Cabot in London, and the couple had two daughters named Catherine and Joan.<ref name=NYPL>Elkind, Elisabeth. [http://archives.nypl.org/the/21762#overview "Guide to the Winthrop Ames Papers, 1908-1931"], Billy Rose Theatre Division, The [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]] (2006)</ref>
===Early career=== In 1904, Ames toured Europe to study the management techniques of sixty opera and theatre companies. Upon his return to America, he became manager of Boston's [[Castle Square Theatre]]. In 1908, he was appointed as the managing director of the [[Century Theatre (New York City)|New Theatre]], at [[Central Park West]] and 62nd Street in New York. In November 1909, the theatre opened officially to the public with an opulent production of ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' starring [[Julia Marlowe]] and [[E. H. Sothern]]. The New Theatre was the largest playhouse in New York City at that time, and Ames began to mount ambitious productions, ranging from Shakespeare and other classics to modern works. The theatre was a financial failure and closed after only two seasons.<ref name=NYPL/>
In 1912, bucking the tide of Broadway commercialism, Ames used his own money to build the [[Helen Hayes Theatre|Little Theatre]] at 240 West 44th Street with the express idea of putting on experimental dramas and to give an opportunity to new playwrights. This theatre had 300 seats and was, at the time, the smallest legitimate theatre in New York. One of the plays he presented in October of the first year of operation was ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1912 play)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'', which he billed as the "First play written entirely for the enjoyment of children." Ames wrote the play under the pseudonym "Jessie Graham White" from the stories of the [[Brothers Grimm]]. The play received favorable reviews. He also built the [[Booth Theatre]] on West 45th Street in 1913 and managed both the Little Theatre and the Booth until 1930.<ref name=NYPL/>
Ames's most notable Broadway productions included an adaptation of ''[[Prunella (fairy tale)|Prunella]]'' (1913), ''[[The Philanderer]]'' (1913), ''A Pair of Silk Stockings'' (1914), and ''Pierrot the Prodigal'' (1916). During [[World War I]], Ames organized the Over There Theatre League, which arranged for actors to travel to Europe to entertain troops.<ref name=NYPL/>
===Later years=== [[File:Cornell-Will-Shakespeare-1923.jpg|thumb|[[Katharine Cornell]] in Ames' production of ''Will Shakespeare'' (1923)]] After the war, Ames began to direct most of the Broadway shows that he produced, including ''The Betrothal'' (1918), ''[[The Green Goddess (stage play)|The Green Goddess]]'' (1921), ''The Truth About Blayds'' (1922), ''Will Shakespeare'' (1923), ''[[Beggar on Horseback]]'' (1924), ''Minick'' (1924), ''Old English'' (1924), ''White Wings'' (1926), ''[[Escape (1927 play)|Escape]]'' (1927), ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' (1928) and ''Mrs. Moonlight'' (1930).
By the 1920s, after the extraordinary success of the [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] works in America at the end of the nineteenth century, the popularity of Gilbert and Sullivan had waned. Ames revived interest in these [[comic opera]]s with lavish and lively seasons of ''[[Iolanthe]]'', ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' and ''[[The Mikado]]'' from 1926 to 1929. Ames directed the productions himself at the Booth Theatre, which received critical praise.<ref>Hurley, G. M. "Gilbert and Sullivan – And Winthrop Ames," ''The New Yorker'', June 6, 1931, p. 70</ref> These paved the way for American tours by the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]] in the 1930s. ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' magazine wrote of Ames' production of ''Iolanthe'': "It is generally agreed that in this entertainment he has done the best job of any producer attempting one of the famous series in our time. The only anxiety now is that he may be distracted before he has revived everyone of the operas in an equally felicitous vein.... The show is now accepted as incomparably the finest musical preparation of its type in town, and probably in the world.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,721953,00.html "New Plays",] ''TIME'' magazine, May 03, 1926</ref>
In the 1920s, Ames began leasing his theatres to other producers, and he produced his last Broadway play in 1930. In 1931, as he wound down his business affairs with age and poor health, he sold the Little Theatre building to ''[[The New York Times]]''. In 1959, the theatre was converted back to a theatre and was briefly renamed in 1964 as the "Winthrop Ames Theatre", and in 1983 it was renamed the [[Helen Hayes Theatre]]. In 1932, Ames left New York to retire to North Easton, but there he helped to found the [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] School of Drama. In 1929, he was elected a trustee of Harvard and in 1936 became vice president of the [[National Institute of Arts and Letters]].
In addition to writing his children's adaptation of ''Snow White'' in 1913, Ames was commissioned by the [[Famous Players-Lasky Corporation]] to write the screenplay for their 1916 [[motion pictures]] ''Oliver Twist'' and ''[[Snow White (1916 film)|Snow White]]''.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0024758/ Winthrop Ames] at the IMDB database</ref> He also translated ''The Merchant of Paris'' from the French in 1930 and wrote other plays.
Ames died of pneumonia in 1937 in [[Boston]] three weeks before his 67th birthday and was buried in North Easton. Like other influential Broadway theater producers, Ames's likeness was captured in caricature by [[Alex Gard]] for the wall of [[Sardi's]], the [[New York City]] [[Theater District]] restaurant. The picture is now part of the collection of the [[New York Public Library]].<ref>[http://www.nypl.org/research/manuscripts/the/thesardis.xml The New York Public Library Inventory of Sardi's Caricatures]</ref>
Ames was inducted, posthumously, into the [[American Theatre Hall of Fame]] in 1981.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/theater/26-elected-theater-hall-fame-26-broadway-voted-into-theater-hall-fame.html "26 Elected to the Theater Hall of Fame."] ''The New York Times'', March 3, 1981.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *MacArthur, David Edward. ''Ames: The Gentleman as Producer-Director'', ''Educational Theatre Journal'', Vol. 16, No. 4 (December, 1964), pp. 349–59, The Johns Hopkins University Press
==External links== {{wikisource author}} *{{IBDB name}} * {{librivox author | id=11278}} *[http://archives.nypl.org/the/21762 Winthrop Ames papers, 1908-1931], held by the Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]] *[http://catalog.nypl.org/record=b19028636~S1 Winthrop Ames diary, 1909-1911], held by the Manuscript and Archives Division, [[New York Public Library]] *[http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/postcards/usa.htm Links to postcards showing scenes from Ames' Gilbert and Sullivan productions] at The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive *{{findagrave|73711908}}
{{Authority control}}
